We force a set of constraints using a verifier $\mathcal{V}[f]$, where $f$ is a verification function returning $\perp$ whenever the adversary misbehaves. We define variants of the concurrent composition of CMs by choosing different verification functions $f$ :

Definition 4.2. For any verification function $f$, the $f$-concurrent composition of CMs is the interactive mechanism $\mathcal{V}[f] \circ^{*} \mathcal{I} \circ^{*}$ ExtConComp.

Differential privacy for the $f$-concurrent composition of CMs follows the standard definition for IMs:

Definition 4.3 (DP for $f$-Concurrent Composition of CMs). For a verification function $f$ and privacy parameter $\epsilon \geq 0$ and $0 \leq \delta \leq 1$, the $f$-concurrent composition of CMs is $(\epsilon, \delta)$-DP against adaptive adversaries if the interactive mechanism $\mathcal{V}[f] \circ^{*} \mathcal{I} \circ^{*}$ ExtConComp is $(\epsilon, \delta)$-DP w.r.t. $\sim_{01}$. Equivalently, this holds if the continual mechanism ExtConComp is $(\epsilon, \delta)$-DP w.r.t. $f$ against adaptive adversaries.

Although verification functions $f$ for ExtConComp vary for different compositions, they must all ensure that the format of the adversary's messages is compatible with $\mathcal{I} \circ^{*}$ ExtConComp. An adversary is expected to either create a new CM or send a pair of queries to an existing one. The creation of a new mechanism is independent of the initial state of $\mathcal{I}$. Thus, when requesting the creation of a new mechanism, the adversary must send a pair of identical creation queries to $\mathcal{V}[f]$. Moreover, due to the definition of $\mathcal{I}$ and ExtConComp, to request asking one of the queries $q_{0}$ and $q_{1}$ from the $i$-th created mechanism according to $\mathcal{I}$ 's initial state, the adversary must send the message $\left(\left(q_{0}, i\right),\left(q_{1}, i\right)\right)$ to $\mathcal{V}[f]$.

Next, we formalize these shared constraints by defining suitable message sequences. Later, when defining specific verification functions $f$ for different concurrent compositions, we set $f\left(m_{1}, \ldots, m_{k}\right)=$ $\perp$ whenever the sequence of messages $m_{1}, \ldots, m_{k}$ is not suitable.
Definition 4.4 (Suitable Sequence of Messages). A sequence of messages $m_{1}, \ldots, m_{k}$ is suitable if for every $1 \leq j \leq k$, (i) $m_{j}$ is of the form $\left(m_{j}^{0}, m_{j}^{1}\right)$, where $m_{j}^{0}$ and $m_{j}^{1}$ are either identical creation queries or messages of the forms $\left(q_{0}, \ell\right)$ and $\left(q_{1}, \ell\right)$ with the same index $\ell$; (ii) for each $b \in\{0,1\}$, if $m_{j}^{b}=(q, \ell)$, then there are at least $\ell$ creation queries in the sequence $m_{1}^{b}, \ldots, m_{j-1}^{b}$; (iii) for each $b \in\{0,1\}$, if $m_{j}^{b}=(q, \ell)$ and $\mathcal{M}_{\ell}$ is the $\ell$-th mechanism requested to be created in $m_{1}^{b}, \ldots, m_{j-1}^{b}$, then $q$ is in the query space of $\mathcal{M}_{\ell}$, i.e., $q \in Q_{\mathcal{M}_{\ell}}$; and (iv) if $m_{j}^{0}=m_{j}^{1}=(\mathcal{M}, s, \epsilon, \delta, f)$, then $\mathcal{M}$ is a CM with a single initial state $s$, and it is $(\epsilon, \delta)$-DP w.r.t. $f$.
4.2. $(\epsilon, \delta)$-DP IMs and $\mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon, \delta}$. Lyu [18] shows that for every $(\epsilon, \delta)$-DP IM $\mathcal{M}$ and every pair of neighboring initial states $s_{0}$ and $s_{1}$, there exists an IPM $\mathcal{T}$ (with a single initial state) such that for each $b \in\{0,1\}$, the mechanisms $\mathcal{T} \circ^{*} \mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon, \delta}(b)$ and $\mathcal{M}\left(s_{b}\right)$ are identical. Vadhan and Wang [20] show the same result in the special case where $\delta=0$.

Although not explicitly stated, the constructions of $\mathcal{T}$ proposed in both [18] and [20] require the answer distributions of $\mathcal{M}\left(s_{0}\right)$ and $\mathcal{M}\left(s_{1}\right)$ to be discrete. This assumption is formally defined as:
Definition 4.5. An IM $\mathcal{M}$ has discrete answer distributions if $A_{\mathcal{M}}$ is countable, and for every initial state $s$, integer $t \in \mathbb{N}$, history $\left(q_{1}, a_{1}, \ldots, q_{t-1}, a_{t-1}\right) \in\left(Q_{\mathcal{M}} \times A_{\mathcal{M}}\right)^{t-1}$, and new query $q_{t} \in Q_{\mathcal{M}}$, the distribution of $\mathcal{M}(s)$ 's answer in respond to $q_{t}$ conditioned on having the history $\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}\right)$ has a probability mass function (PMF).

This is generally not a restrictive assumption in differential privacy. In practice, the binary nature of computers and the fact that the total number of memory bits in the world is finite ensure that every distribution sampled computationally is inherently discrete. Theoretically, when dealing with real-valued outputs, one can enforce discrete answer distributions by rounding each output to the nearest multiple of a sufficiently small constant $\alpha$. This discretization post-processing preserves the privacy of the mechanism and has a negligible effect on the accuracy. An example of this approach will be provided in Section 7.

Lyu [18] additionally assumes that there exists a pre-fixed upper bound $c$ on the number of queries $\mathcal{M}$ answers. In Appendix A, we will modify their proof to remove this additional assumption. Let $\mathcal{M}^{\prime}$ be a continual mechanism that is $(\epsilon, \delta)$-DP w.r.t. a verification function $f$. By Corollary 3.8, $\mathcal{V}[f] \circ^{*} \mathcal{I} \circ^{*} \mathcal{M}^{\prime}$ is an IM that is $(\epsilon, \delta)$-DP w.r.t. $\sim_{01}$. Replacing $\mathcal{M}$ in Lemma A. 1 with $\mathcal{V}[f] \circ^{*} \mathcal{I} \circ^{*} \mathcal{M}^{\prime}$, we get:

Lemma 4.6 ([18]). For $\epsilon>0$ and $0 \leq \delta \leq 1$, let $\mathcal{M}$ be a CM that is $(\epsilon, \delta)$-DP w.r.t. a verification function $f$. Suppose $\mathcal{V}[f] \circ^{*} \mathcal{I} \circ^{*} \mathcal{M}$ has discrete answer distributions and responds to at most $c$ queries. Then, there exists an IPM $\mathcal{T}$ with a single initial state () such that for each $b \in\{0,1\}$, the IMs $\mathcal{T} \circ^{*} \mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon, \delta}(b)$ and $\mathcal{V}[f] \circ^{*} \mathcal{I}(b) \circ^{*} \mathcal{M}$ are equivalent.

Let $\mathcal{M}$ be an IM that is $\epsilon$-DP w.r.t. a neighbor relation $\sim$. For every pair of neighboring initial states $s_{0}$ and $s_{1}$, Vadhan and Wang [20] construct an IPM $\mathcal{T}$ (with a single initial state) such that for each bit $b \in\{0,1\}$, the mechanisms $\mathcal{T} \circ^{*} \mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon, 0}(b)$ and $\mathcal{M}\left(s_{b}\right)$ are identical. Appendix B, we will review their construction and show that for any query sequence $q_{1}, \ldots, q_{t}$, if the distributions of the $t$ answers of $\mathcal{M}\left(s_{0}\right)$ and $\mathcal{M}\left(s_{1}\right)$ to the queries $q_{1}, \ldots, q_{t}$ are identical, then $\mathcal{T}$ does not need to know the output of $\mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon, 0}(b)$ in the first $t$ steps. This observation allows us to delay the interaction of $\mathcal{T}$ and $\operatorname{RR}_{\epsilon, 0}(b)$ as much as possible.

Let $\mathcal{M}=\mathcal{V}[f] \circ^{*} \mathcal{I} \circ^{*} \mathcal{M}^{\prime}$, where $\mathcal{M}^{\prime}$ is an $\epsilon$-DP CM w.r.t. $f$. By definition, upon receiving a query sequence $q_{1}, \ldots, q_{t}$ where each $q_{j}=\left(q_{j}^{\prime}, q_{j}^{\prime}\right)$ is a pair of identical queries, $\mathcal{V}[f] \circ^{*} \mathcal{I}(0) \circ^{*} \mathcal{M}^{\prime}$ and $\mathcal{V}[f] \circ^{*} \mathcal{I}(1) \circ^{*} \mathcal{M}^{\prime}$ have the same answer distribution, implying the following lemma:

Lemma 4.7 ([20]). For $\epsilon \geq 0$, let $\mathcal{M}$ be a CM that is $\epsilon$-DP w.r.t. a verification function $f$. Suppose $\mathcal{V}[f] \circ^{*} \mathcal{I} \circ^{*} \mathcal{M}$ has discrete answer distributions. Then, there exists an IPM $\mathcal{T}$ with a single initial state () such that for each $b \in\{0,1\}$,

- the IMs $\mathcal{T} \circ^{*} \mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon, 0}(b)$ and $\mathcal{V}[f] \circ^{*} \mathcal{I}(b) \circ^{*} \mathcal{M}$ are equivalent, and
- as long as $\mathcal{T}$ receives pairs of identical queries, it does not interact with $\mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon, 0}(b)$.

Remark 4.8. Since $\mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon, \delta}$ is a NIM, in both Lemma 4.6 and Lemma 4.7, the IPM $\mathcal{T}$ interacts with $\mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon, \delta}$ at most once.
4.3. Concurrent Composition of CMs $\mathcal{M}_{1}, \ldots, \mathcal{M}_{k}$. For $1 \leq i \leq k$, let $\mathcal{M}_{i}$ be a CM with the initial state space $S_{i}=\left\{s_{i}\right\}$ such that $\mathcal{M}_{i}$ is $\left(\epsilon_{i}, \delta_{i}\right)$-DP w.r.t. a verification function $f_{i}$, and $\mathcal{V}\left[f_{i}\right] \circ^{*} \mathcal{I} \circ^{*} \mathcal{M}_{i}$ has discrete answer distributions. In the concurrent composition of $\mathcal{M}_{1}, \ldots, \mathcal{M}_{k}$, an adversary is restricted to the following steps: (1) It first creates the fixed mechanisms $\mathcal{M}_{1}, \ldots, \mathcal{M}_{k}$ and (2) then adaptively issues pairs of queries for them such that the sequences of query pairs for each $\mathcal{M}_{i}$ is $f_{i}$-valid. Note that creating the $\mathrm{CM} \mathcal{M}_{i}$ means creating an instance of $\mathcal{M}_{i}\left(s_{i}\right)$, where $s_{i}$ is the unique initial state of $\mathcal{M}_{i}$. Based on a secret bit $b \in\{0,1\}$, each CM either receives the first element of every query pair addressed to it or the second element, and the adversary tries to guess $b$ using the answers of all $k$ mechanisms.

To formalize this type of concurrent composition of CMs, we introduce the verification function $f^{\alpha_{1}, \ldots, \alpha_{k}}$. Intuitively, this verification function enforces that the adversary creates the mechanisms $\mathcal{M}_{1}, \ldots, \mathcal{M}_{k}$ in their first $k$ messages and then only sends messages containing pairs of queries for $\mathcal{M}_{i}$ s. Additionally, it ensures that the sequence of query pairs for each $\mathcal{M}_{i}$ is $f_{i}$-valid. The formal definition of $f^{\alpha_{1}, \ldots, \alpha_{k}}$ is as follows:

Definition 4.9 $\left(f^{\alpha_{1}, \ldots, \alpha_{k}}\right)$. For $i \in[k]$, let $\alpha_{i}=\left(\mathcal{M}_{i}, s_{i}, \epsilon_{i}, \delta_{i}, f_{i}\right)$ denote a creation query. For any input sequence of messages $m_{1}, \ldots, m_{t}$, the outcome of $f^{\alpha_{1}, \ldots, \alpha_{k}}$ returns $\top$ if and only if all of the following conditions hold:
(i) The sequence $m_{1}, \ldots, m_{k}$ is suitable. For $j \in[t]$, let $m_{j}=\left(m_{j}^{0}, m_{j}^{1}\right)$.
(ii) For $j \leq \min \{t, k\}$, the messages $m_{j}^{0}=m_{j}^{1}=\alpha_{j}$.
(iii) For $i \in[k]$, the sequence of $\left(q^{0}, q^{1}\right)$ s in the messages of the form $\left(\left(q^{0}, i\right),\left(q^{1}, i\right)\right)$ is $f_{i}$-valid.

With the above definition of $f^{\alpha_{1}, \ldots, \alpha_{k}}$, we refer to the $f^{\alpha_{1}, \ldots, \alpha_{k}}$-concurrent composition of CMs as the concurrent composition of the continual mechanisms $\mathcal{M}_{1}, \ldots, \mathcal{M}_{k}$. Therefore, the concurrent composition of $\mathcal{M}_{1}, \ldots, \mathcal{M}_{k}$ is $(\epsilon, \delta)$-DP against adaptive adversaries if ExtConComp is $(\epsilon, \delta)$-DP w.r.t. $f^{\alpha_{1}, \ldots, \alpha_{k}}$ against adaptive adversaries.

Recall that in Section 3, we generalized the notion of neighboring relations for interactive mechanisms to verification functions for continual mechanisms. The neighboring initial states for an interactive mechanism are chosen non-adaptively at initialization. However, the choice of messages forming a valid sequence w.r.t. a verification function is adaptive and happens over time. That is, an adversary generates two different query sequences for a CM, and the choice of differing sequences is made adaptively throughout the interaction.

In the concurrent composition of IMs, queries to each mechanism are chosen adaptively, not only based on that mechanism's previous responses but also using the responses of the other mechanisms up to that point. By definition, the choice of neighboring initial states for the interactive mechanisms is non-adaptive. However, in the concurrent composition of CMs, the choice of differences between query sequences, i.e., the neighboring query sequences is adaptive, based on not only the responses of the corresponding mechanism but also the responses of other mechanisms. (Note that, unlike IMs, CMs inherently have a single fixed initial state; hence, no choice of initial state is involved.) Despite this additional adaptivity, in the following theorem, we show that the privacy results of [18] for $\operatorname{ConComp}\left[\mathcal{M}_{1}, \ldots, \mathcal{M}_{k}\right]$ also hold for $\mathcal{V}\left[f^{\alpha_{1}, \ldots, \alpha_{k}}\right] \circ^{*} \mathcal{I} \circ^{*}$ ExtConComp.

Theorem 4.10. For $1 \leq i \leq k$, let $\mathcal{M}_{i}$ be a continual mechanism with initial state space $S_{\mathcal{M}_{i}}^{\text {init }}=\left\{s_{i}\right\}$ such that $\mathcal{M}_{i}$ is $\left(\epsilon_{i}, \delta_{i}\right)$-DP w.r.t. a verification function $f_{i}$ against adaptive adversaries, and $\mathcal{V}\left[f_{i}\right] \circ^{*} \mathcal{I} \circ^{*} \mathcal{M}_{i}$ has discrete answer distributions. For $\epsilon>0$ and $0 \leq \delta \leq 1$, if the composition of non-interactive mechanisms $\mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon_{1}, \delta_{1}}, \ldots, \mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon_{k}, \delta_{k}}$ is $(\epsilon, \delta)$-DP, then the concurrent composition of $\mathcal{M}_{1}, \ldots, \mathcal{M}_{k}$ is also $(\epsilon, \delta)$-DP against adaptive adversaries.

Proof. Let $\alpha_{i}=\left(\mathcal{M}_{i}, s_{i}, \epsilon_{i}, \delta_{i}, f_{i}\right)$ for each $i \in[k]$, and let $f$ denote $f^{\alpha_{1}, \ldots, \alpha_{k}}$ for simplicity. Our goal is to show that ExtConComp is $(\epsilon, \delta)$-DP w.r.t. $f$. To prove so, we construct an IPM $\mathcal{P}$ with a single initial state and show that for each $b \in\{0,1\}$, the mechanisms $\mathcal{V}[f] \circ^{*} \mathcal{I}(b) \circ^{*}$ ExtConComp and $\mathcal{V}[f] \circ^{*} \mathcal{P} \circ^{*} \operatorname{Comp}\left[\mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon_{1}, \delta_{1}}, \ldots, \mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon_{k}, \delta_{k}}\right]((b)_{\epsilon=1}^{k})$ are equivalent.

Since $\mathcal{V}[f] \circ^{*} \mathcal{P}$ is an IPM with a single initial state, Lemma 2.15 implies that if $\operatorname{Comp}\left[\mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon_{1}, \delta_{1}}, \ldots, \mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon_{k}, \delta_{k}}\right]$ is $(\epsilon, \delta)$-DP, then $\mathcal{V}[f] \circ^{*} \mathcal{P} \circ^{*} \operatorname{Comp}\left[\mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon_{1}, \delta_{1}}, \ldots, \mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon_{k}, \delta_{k}}\right]$ is also $(\epsilon, \delta)$ DP. Hence, for any adversary $\mathcal{A}$, the views of $\mathcal{A}$ when interacting with the mechanisms $\mathcal{V}[f] \circ^{*} \mathcal{P} \circ^{*} \operatorname{Comp}\left[\mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon_{1}, \delta_{1}}, \ldots, \mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon_{k}, \delta_{k}}\right]((0)_{\epsilon=1}^{k})$ and $\mathcal{V}[f] \circ^{*} \mathcal{P} \circ^{*} \operatorname{Comp}\left[\mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon_{1}, \delta_{1}}, \ldots, \mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon_{k}, \delta_{k}}\right]((1)_{\epsilon=1}^{k})$ are $(\epsilon, \delta)$-indistinguishable. As we will show below, by construction, these views are identical to those obtained by interacting with the original mechanisms $\mathcal{V}[f] \circ^{*} \mathcal{I}(b) \circ^{*}$ ExtConComp, implying that the concurrent composition of $\mathcal{M}_{1}, \ldots, \mathcal{M}_{k}$ is $(\epsilon, \delta)$-DP.

In $\mathcal{V}[f] \circ^{*} \mathcal{I}(b) \circ^{*}$ ExtConComp, when $\mathcal{I}(b)$ receives pairs of identical creation queries from $\mathcal{V}[f]$, it forwards one of them to ExtConComp, which then creates an instance of $\mathcal{M}_{i}$ and returns $\top$. Subsequently, when $\mathcal{I}(b)$ receives two queries for $\mathcal{M}_{i}$, it forwards them to $\mathcal{M}_{i}$ through ExtConComp and returns its response. This procedure can be equivalently represented by an IM $\operatorname{IECC}(b)$ as follows: when receiving pairs of identical creation queries from $\mathcal{V}[f], \operatorname{IECC}(b)$ creates an instance of $\mathcal{V}\left[f_{i}\right] \circ^{*} \mathcal{I}(b) \circ^{*} \mathcal{M}_{i}$ and returns $\top$. Subsequently, when receiving $\left(\left(q_{0}, i\right),\left(q_{1}, i\right)\right)$, it forwards $\left(q_{0}, q_{1}\right)$ to $\mathcal{V}\left[f_{i}\right] \circ^{*} \mathcal{I}(b) \circ^{*} \mathcal{M}_{i}$ and returns its response. By definition of $f$ and $\mathcal{I}$, the mechanisms

$\mathcal{V}[f] \circ^{*} \mathcal{I}(b) \circ^{*}$ ExtConComp and $\mathcal{V}[f] \circ^{*} \operatorname{IECC}(b)$ are equivalent. Next, we define $\mathcal{P}$ explicitly and show $\mathcal{V}[f] \circ^{*} \operatorname{IECC}(b)$ and $\mathcal{V}[f] \circ^{*} \mathcal{P} \circ^{*}$ Comp $\left[\mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon_{1}, \delta_{1}}, \ldots, \mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon_{k}, \delta_{k}}\right]((b)_{\epsilon=1}^{k})$ are equivalent.

Let $\mathcal{T}_{i}$ be the IPM for $\mathcal{M}_{i}$ given by Lemma 4.6, and let $t_{i}$ be its single initial state. The initial state of $\mathcal{P}$ is a pair of empty sequences. Let $\left(\sigma_{1}, \sigma_{2}\right)$ denote the state of $\mathcal{P}$. When receiving the first left message, $\mathcal{P}$ interacts with its right mechanism, Comp $\left[\mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon_{1}, \delta_{1}}, \ldots, \mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon_{k}, \delta_{k}}\right]((b)_{\epsilon=1}^{k})$, and sets $\sigma_{1}$ to its output sequence $\left(r_{1}, \ldots, r_{k}\right) . \mathcal{P}$ never interacts with its right mechanism again.

Upon receiving a left message $\left(\mathcal{M}_{i}, s_{i}, \epsilon_{i}, \delta_{i}, f_{i}\right)^{2}, \mathcal{P}$ adds $\left(\mathcal{T}_{i}, t_{i}\right)$ to $\sigma_{2}$ and returns $\top$. Moreover, upon receiving a left message $\left(\left(q_{0}, i\right),\left(q_{1}, i\right)\right), \mathcal{P}$ sends $\left(q_{0}, q_{1}\right)$ as a left message to $\mathcal{T}_{i}$ and returns its response. If $\mathcal{T}_{i}$ requests a sample from $\mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon_{i}, \delta_{i}}, \mathcal{P}$ provides it with the previously stored sample $r_{i}$. Formally, $\mathcal{P}$ executes $\left(t_{i}, v, m\right) \leftarrow \mathcal{T}_{i}\left(t_{i}, \mathrm{~L},\left(q_{0}, q_{1}\right)\right)$ and as long as $v=\mathrm{R}$, it runs $\left(t_{i}, v, m\right) \leftarrow \mathcal{T}_{i}\left(t_{i}, v, r_{i}\right)$. Once $v=\mathrm{L}, \mathcal{P}$ returns the message $m$ to $\mathcal{V}[f]$. (By Remark 4.8, $v=\mathrm{R}$ at most once.) By Lemma 4.6, each $\mathcal{T}_{i}$, provided with the sample $r_{i}$ from $\mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon_{i}, \delta_{i}}$, simulates $\mathcal{V}\left[f_{i}\right] \circ^{*} \mathcal{I}(b) \circ^{*} \mathcal{M}_{i}$ identically. Hence, by definition of IECC and $\mathcal{P}$, the mechanisms $\operatorname{IECC}(b)$ and $\mathcal{P} \circ^{*} \operatorname{Comp}\left[\mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon_{1}, \delta_{1}}, \ldots, \mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon_{k}, \delta_{k}}\right]((b)_{\epsilon=1}^{k})$ are equivalent, finishing the proof.
4.4. Concurrent Composition of CMs with Fixed Parameters. The concurrent composition of CMs with fixed parameters generalizes the concurrent composition of fixed CMs by allowing the adversary to select the CMs $\mathcal{M}_{1}, \ldots, \mathcal{M}_{k}$ adaptively over time, instead of forcing them to create a fixed set of mechanisms in their first $k$ messages. Each selected mechanism $\mathcal{M}_{i}$ must be $\left(\epsilon_{i}, \delta_{i}\right)$-DP w.r.t. a verification function $f_{i}$, where the multiset of privacy parameters $\left(\epsilon_{1}, \delta_{1}\right), \ldots,\left(\epsilon_{k}, \delta_{k}\right)$ is fixed in advance, but the verification functions $f_{i}$ are chosen by the adversary. Note that this implies that at most $k$ continual mechanism are created by the adversary. Moreover, due to the aforementioned technical reasons, each $\mathcal{V}\left[f_{i}\right] \circ^{*} \mathcal{I} \circ^{*} \mathcal{M}_{i}$ must have discrete answer distributions.

For instance, an adversary may first create a continual mechanism $\mathcal{M}_{3}$ that is $\left(\epsilon_{3}, \delta_{3}\right)$-DP w.r.t. a verification function $f_{3}$. Then, after interacting with $\mathcal{M}_{3}$ for some time and analyzing its responses, the adversary may then select a mechanism $\mathcal{M}_{1}$ from the class of $\left(\epsilon_{1}, \delta_{1}\right)$-DP CMs. Similar to the concurrent composition of fixed CMs, the adversary's sequence of query pairs for each $\mathcal{M}_{i}$ must be $f_{i}$-valid.

To formally define this composition, we introduce a verification function, $f^{\epsilon_{1}, \delta_{1}, \ldots, \epsilon_{k}, \delta_{k}}$ as follows:
Definition 4.11 $\left(f^{\epsilon_{1}, \delta_{1}, \ldots, \epsilon_{k}, \delta_{k}}\right)$. For any input sequence of messages $m_{1}, \ldots, m_{t}$, the function $f^{\epsilon_{1}, \delta_{1}, \ldots, \epsilon_{k}, \delta_{k}}$ returns $\top$ if and only if all of the following conditions hold:
(i) The sequence $m_{1}, \ldots, m_{t}$ is suitable.
(ii) There are at most $k$ pairs of identical creation queries in the sequence $m_{1}, \ldots, m_{t}$. Let $\mathcal{M}_{i}^{\prime}$ denote the $i$-th created mechanism and $\left(\epsilon_{i}^{\prime}, \delta_{i}^{\prime}\right)$ and $f_{i}^{\prime}$ be its privacy parameters and verification function, respectively. $\mathcal{V}\left[f_{i}^{\prime}\right] \circ^{*} \mathcal{I} \circ^{*} \mathcal{M}_{i}^{\prime}$ has discrete answer distributions. Moreover, the multiset of the privacy parameters $\left(\epsilon_{i}^{\prime}, \delta_{i}^{\prime}\right)$ of the created mechanisms is a sub-multiset of the fixed privacy parameters $\left(\epsilon_{1}, \delta_{1}\right), \ldots,\left(\epsilon_{k}, \delta_{k}\right)$. Note that $\left(\epsilon_{i}^{\prime}, \delta_{i}^{\prime}\right)$ is adaptively chosen by the adversary, while $\left(\epsilon_{i}, \delta_{i}\right)$ is a predetermined publicly-known parameter.
(iii) For each $i \in[k]$, the sequence of $\left(q^{0}, q^{1}\right)$ s in the messages of the form $\left(\left(q^{0}, i\right),\left(q^{1}, i\right)\right)$ is $f_{i}^{\prime}$-valid.

We refer to the $f^{\epsilon_{1}, \delta_{1}, \ldots, \epsilon_{k}, \delta_{k}}$-concurrent composition of CMs as the concurrent composition of CMs with privacy parameters $\left(\left(\epsilon_{i}, \delta_{i}\right)\right)_{i=1}^{k}$. A slight adaptation of the proof of Theorem 4.10 implies the following theorem.

Theorem 4.12. For $\epsilon, \epsilon_{1}, \ldots, \epsilon_{k}>0$ and $0 \leq \delta, \delta_{1}, \ldots, \delta_{k} \leq 1$, if the composition of non-interactive mechanisms $\mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon_{1}, \delta_{1}}, \ldots, \mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon_{k}, \delta_{k}}$ is $(\epsilon, \delta)$-DP, then the concurrent composition of $k$ CMs with the privacy parameters $\left(\left(\epsilon_{i}, \delta_{i}\right)\right)_{i=1}^{k}$ is also $(\epsilon, \delta)$-DP against adaptive adversaries.

Proof. The proof is identical to the proof of Theorem 4.10 with the following modification in the construction of $\mathcal{P}$ : Recall that $\left(r_{1}, \ldots, r_{k}\right)$ denotes the output of $\operatorname{Comp}\left[\mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon_{1}, \delta_{1}}, \ldots, \mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon_{k}, \delta_{k}}\right]$. In the proof of Theorem 4.10, the $i$-th creation query was known to be $\left(\mathcal{M}_{i}, s_{i}, \epsilon_{i}, \delta_{i}, f_{i}\right)$. Consequently, $\mathcal{T}_{i}$

expected $\mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon_{i}, \delta_{i}}$ as its right mechanism, and when $\mathcal{T}_{i}$ needed a response from its right mechanism, $\mathcal{P}$ sent $r_{i}$ to it. However, in the concurrent composition with fixed parameters, the IPM requesting the sample from $\mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon_{i}, \delta_{i}}$ need not necessarily be $\mathcal{T}_{i}$. To handle this, we modify $\mathcal{P}$ so that it maps each output sample $r_{i}$ to the appropriate IPM $\mathcal{T}_{j}$ needing a sample from $\mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon_{i}, \delta_{i}}$.

Let $\left(\mathcal{M}_{j}^{\prime}, s_{j}^{\prime}, \epsilon_{j}^{\prime}, \delta_{j}^{\prime}, f_{j}^{\prime}\right)^{2}$ denote the $j$-th pair of identical creation queries received by $\mathcal{P}$ from the verifier, and let $\mathcal{T}_{j}$ be the corresponding IPM given by Lemma 4.6. When $\mathcal{T}_{j}$ requests a sample from $\mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon_{j}^{\prime}, \delta_{j}^{\prime}}, \mathcal{P}$ iterates over $\sigma_{1}$ to find the smallest $i^{*} \in[k]$ such that the $i^{*}$-th element of $\sigma_{1}$ is not null and $\epsilon_{j}^{\prime}=\epsilon_{i^{*}}, \delta_{j}^{\prime}=\delta_{i^{*}}$. After sending $r_{i^{*}}$ to $\mathcal{T}_{j}, \mathcal{P}$ updates $\sigma_{1}$ and sets $r_{i}$ to null. This adjustment ensures that even when there are duplicate privacy parameters among $\left(\epsilon_{1}, \delta_{1}\right), \ldots,\left(\epsilon_{k}, \delta_{k}\right)$, each sample $r_{i}$ is sent to at most one $\mathcal{T}_{j}$. Note that by the definition of $f^{\epsilon_{1}, \delta_{1}, \ldots, \epsilon_{k}, \delta_{k}}, i^{*}$ always exists.

# 5. Concurrent Parallel Composition of CMs 

The concurrent $k$-sparse parallel composition extends the concurrent composition of CMs with $k$ fixed parameters by permitting the creation of an arbitrary number of CMs. Specifically, given a multiset params of $k$ privacy parameters $\left(\epsilon_{1}, \delta_{1}\right), \ldots,\left(\epsilon_{k}, \delta_{k}\right)$, the adversary can create an unlimited number of CMs with arbitrary privacy parameters. However, the adversary must ask pairs of identical queries to all created mechanisms, except for at most $k$ of them. Let $\mathcal{M}_{1}, \ldots, \mathcal{M}_{k}$ be these exceptional mechanisms. Each $\mathcal{M}_{i}$, selected by the adversary, must be $\left(\epsilon_{i}, \delta_{i}\right)$-DP w.r.t. a verification function $f_{i}$ and with $\left(\epsilon_{i}, \delta_{i}\right) \in$ params, and the sequence of query pairs for $\mathcal{M}_{i}$ must be $f_{i}$-valid.

In Section 5.1, we formally define this composition and extend the result of Theorem 4.12 to the concurrent $k$-sparse parallel composition of CMs when $\delta_{1}=\cdots=\delta_{k}=0$. In Section 5.2, we provide a counter example that demonstrates why such an extension is impossible for $\delta_{j}>0$.

In Section 5.3, we restrict the verification functions $f_{i}$ of the $k$ mechanisms receiving neighboring input and we show that Theorem 4.12 holds for the concurrent $k$-sparse parallel composition of CM in this scenario without any constraints on the values of $\delta_{j}$.
5.1. Definition and Composition Theorem for Pure DP. To formally define the concurrent $k$-sparse parallel composition of CMs with parameters $\left(\left(\epsilon_{i}, \delta_{i}\right)\right)_{i=1}^{k}$, we introduce the verification function $f_{\infty}^{\epsilon_{1}, \delta_{1}, \ldots, \epsilon_{k}, \delta_{k}}$, where the subscript $\infty$ emphasizes that an unbounded number of CMs can be created.

Definition 5.1 $\left(f_{\infty}^{\epsilon_{1}, \delta_{1}, \ldots, \epsilon_{k}, \delta_{k}}\right)$. For any input sequence of messages $m_{1}, \ldots, m_{t}$, the function $f_{\infty}^{\epsilon_{1}, \delta_{1}, \ldots, \epsilon_{k}, \delta_{k}}$ returns $\top$ if and only if all of the following conditions hold:
(i) The sequence $m_{1}, \ldots, m_{t}$ is suitable.
(ii) Let $\mathcal{M}_{i}^{\prime}$ denote the $i$-th created mechanism and $\left(\epsilon_{i}^{\prime}, \delta_{i}^{\prime}\right)$ and $f_{i}^{\prime}$ be its privacy parameters and verification function, respectively. Define $\mathcal{J}$ as the set of indices $j$ such that there exists a message $\left(\left(q_{0}, j\right),\left(q_{1}, j\right)\right)$ where $q_{0} \neq q_{1}$. Let params $_{\mathcal{J}}$ denote the multiset consisting of privacy parameters $\left(\epsilon_{j}^{\prime}, \delta_{j}^{\prime}\right)$ for each $j \in \mathcal{J}$. This condition requires that params $_{\mathcal{J}}$ be a sub-multiset of the fixed privacy parameters $\left(\epsilon_{1}, \delta_{1}\right), \ldots,\left(\epsilon_{k}, \delta_{k}\right)$. Note that this implies that $|\mathcal{J}| \leq k$.
(iii) For every $j \in \mathcal{J}$, the sequence of $\left(q_{0}, q_{1}\right) s$ in the messages of the form $\left(\left(q_{0}, j\right),\left(q_{1}, j\right)\right)$ must be $f_{i}$-valid. Note that by definition, for every index $j \notin \mathcal{J}$ and every message of the form $\left(\left(q_{0}, j\right),\left(q_{1}, j\right)\right)$, it holds that $q_{0}=q_{1}$.

We refer to the $f_{\infty}^{\epsilon_{1}, \delta_{1}, \ldots, \epsilon_{k}, \delta_{k}}$-concurrent composition of CMs as the concurrent $k$-sparse parallel composition of CMs with privacy parameters $\left(\left(\epsilon_{i}, \delta_{i}\right)\right)_{i=1}^{k}$. Therefore, this composition is $(\epsilon, \delta)$ DP against adaptive adversaries if ExtConComp is $(\epsilon, \delta)$-DP w.r.t. $f_{\infty}^{\epsilon_{1}, \delta_{1}, \ldots, \epsilon_{k}, \delta_{k}}$ against adaptive adversaries.

Theorem 5.2. For $\epsilon, \epsilon_{1}, \ldots, \epsilon_{k} \geq 0$ and $0 \leq \delta \leq 1$, if the composition of non-interactive mechanisms $\mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon_{1}, 0}, \ldots, \mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon_{k}, 0}$ is $(\epsilon, \delta)$-DP, then the concurrent $k$-sparse parallel composition of CMs with the privacy parameters $\left(\epsilon_{1}, 0\right), \ldots,\left(\epsilon_{k}, 0\right)$ is also $(\epsilon, \delta)$-DP against an adaptive adversary.

Proof. The proof is identical to the proof of Theorem 4.12, except for the definition of IPMs $\mathcal{T}_{j}$ that are executed by the IPM $\mathcal{P}$. Let $\left(\mathcal{M}_{j}^{\prime}, s_{j}^{\prime}, \epsilon_{j}^{\prime}, \delta_{j}^{\prime}, f_{j}^{\prime}\right)^{2}$ denote the $j$-th pair of identical creation queries received by $\mathcal{P}$ from $\mathcal{V}[f]$. To ensure that the proof of Theorem 4.12 remains valid, we must guarantee that the newly defined IPMs $\mathcal{T}_{j}$ satisfy the following properties needed by the proof of Theorem 4.12. These are the only properties that this proof requires for the $\mathcal{T}_{j} \mathrm{~s}$ :

- The mechanisms $\mathcal{T}_{j} \circ^{*} \mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon_{j}^{\prime}, \delta_{j}^{\prime}}(b)$ and $\mathcal{V}\left[f_{j}^{\prime}\right] \circ^{*} \mathcal{I}(b) \circ^{*} \mathcal{M}_{j}^{\prime}$ are equivalent, and
- the multiset of privacy parameters $\left(\epsilon_{j}^{\prime}, \delta_{j}^{\prime}\right)$ corresponding to IMPs $\mathcal{T}_{j}$ that are interacting with their right mechanism $\mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon_{j}^{\prime}, \delta_{j}^{\prime}}(b)$ is a sub-multiset of $\left(\epsilon_{1}, 0\right), \ldots,\left(\epsilon_{k}, 0\right)$, implying that the remaining $\mathcal{T}_{j}$ never interact with a $\mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon_{j}^{\prime}, \delta_{j}^{\prime}}(b)$.
The new definition of $\mathcal{T}_{j}$ is as follows:
- If $\delta_{j}^{\prime}>0$, then $\mathcal{T}_{j}$ acts identical to $\mathcal{V}\left[f_{j}^{\prime}\right] \circ^{*} \mathcal{I}(0) \circ^{*} \mathcal{M}_{j}^{\prime}: \mathcal{T}_{j}$ has a single initial state $\left((), 0, s^{\text {init }}\right)$, where $s^{\text {init }}$ is the single initial state of $\mathcal{M}_{j}^{\prime}$. Upon receiving a right message, $\mathcal{T}_{j}$ halts the communication, and upon receiving a left message, it updates its state and responds identically to $\mathcal{V}\left[f_{j}^{\prime}\right] \circ^{*} \mathcal{I}(0) \circ^{*} \mathcal{M}_{j}^{\prime}$.
- If $\delta_{j}^{\prime}=0$, then $\mathcal{T}_{j}$ is the IPM corresponding to $\mathcal{M}_{j}^{\prime}$ given by Lemma 4.7.

By Definition 5.1 (ii), if $\delta_{j}^{\prime}>0$, then all future messages $\left(\left(q_{0}, j\right),\left(q_{1}, j\right)\right)$ satisfy $q_{0}=q_{1}$. Therefore, by the above definition, for each $b \in\{0,1\}$, the mechanisms $\mathcal{T}_{j} \circ^{*} \mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon_{j}^{\prime}, \delta_{j}^{\prime}}(b)$ and $\mathcal{V}\left[f_{j}^{\prime}\right] \circ^{*} \mathcal{I}(b) \circ^{*} \mathcal{M}_{j}^{\prime}$ are identical, and $\mathcal{T}_{j}$ never interacts with $\operatorname{RR}_{\epsilon_{j}^{\prime}, \delta_{j}^{\prime}}(b)$.

Moreover, when $\delta_{j}^{\prime}=0$, by Definition 5.1 (iii), Lemma 4.7, and Remark 4.8, for each $b \in\{0,1\}$, the mechanisms $\mathcal{T}_{j} \circ^{*} \mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon_{j}^{\prime}, \delta_{j}^{\prime}}(b)$ and $\mathcal{V}\left[f_{j}^{\prime}\right] \circ^{*} \mathcal{I}(b) \circ^{*} \mathcal{M}_{j}^{\prime}$ are identical, and $\mathcal{T}_{j}$ interacts with $\operatorname{RR}_{\epsilon_{j}^{\prime}, \delta_{j}^{\prime}}(b)$ at most once after receiving a pair of non-identical queries.

In the concurrent $k$-sparse parallel composition, an unlimited number of CMs can be created, but only at most $k$ of them (here, with $\delta_{j}^{\prime}=0$ ) can receive non-identical query pairs. By Definition 5.1 (ii), the privacy parameters of these mechanisms is a sub-multiset of $\left(\epsilon_{1}, 0\right), \ldots,\left(\epsilon_{k}, 0\right)$. By design, the IPMs $\mathcal{T}_{j}$ corresponding to these mechanisms may require a sample from $\mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon_{j}^{\prime}, 0}$.
5.2. Counter Example. In this section, we illustrate that extending the result of Theorem 5.2 to general $\delta_{j}>0$ is impossible. Specifically, let $k=1, \epsilon_{1}=0$, and $\delta_{1}=\delta \in(0,1]$. We construct, an adversary $\mathcal{A}_{\delta}$ that interacts with $\mathcal{V}\left[f^{0, \delta}\right] \circ^{*} \mathcal{I}(b) \circ^{*}$ ExtConComp and successfully determines the secret bit $b \in\{0,1\}$. Our construction proceeds in three steps: (1) introducing a verification function $g$, (2) constructing a CM $\mathcal{M}_{\delta}$ that is $(0, \delta)$-DP w.r.t. $g$, and (3) designing $\mathcal{A}_{\delta}$.

Step 1 (Introducing $g$ ): The verification function $g$ accepts a message sequence $\left(m_{1}, \ldots, m_{t}\right)$ and returns $\top$ if and only if (i) $t \leq 2$, (ii) each $m_{j}$ is a pair of binary numbers $\left(b_{j}, b_{j}^{\prime}\right) \in\{0,1\}^{2}$, and (ii) the sequences $\left(b_{1}, \ldots, b_{t}\right)$ and $\left(b_{1}^{\prime}, \ldots, b_{t}^{\prime}\right)$ differ in at most a single element.
Step 2 (Constructing $\mathcal{M}_{\delta}$ ): The CM $\mathcal{M}_{\delta}:\{\perp, \top\} \times\{0,1\} \rightarrow\{\perp, \top\} \times\{0,1, \top, \perp\}$ with the initial state space $\{\top\}$ is defined as follows:

- $\mathcal{M}_{\delta}$ maps state $\top$ and an input message $b \in\{0,1\}$ to state $\top$ and output message $\top$ with probability $1-\delta$ and to state $\perp$ and output message $\perp$ with probability $\delta$.
- $\mathcal{M}_{\delta}$ maps state $\perp$ and an input message $b \in\{0,1\}$ to state $\perp$ and output message $b$ with probability 1 .
Thus, $\mathcal{M}_{\delta}$ has two possible states, $\top$ and $\perp$, and accepts binary queries. Initially, $\mathcal{M}_{\delta}$ starts in state $\top$. On the first query, independent of the value of $b$, it switches to state $\perp$ with probability $\delta$ and returns its final state as an output message. On the second query, if the state is $\top$, the same

as the first query, it switches to state $\perp$ with probability $\delta$ and returns the final state as output. However, if the state is $\perp, \mathcal{M}_{\delta}$ outputs the exact input message $b$.

Since with probability $1-\delta$, the first two outputs of $\mathcal{M}_{\delta}$ are independent of the input, $\mathcal{M}_{\delta}$ is $(0, \delta)$-DP w.r.t. the verification function $g$.
Step 3 (Designing $\mathcal{A}_{\delta}$ ): In the interaction with $\mathcal{V}\left[f^{0, \delta}\right] \circ^{*} \mathcal{I}(b) \circ^{*}$ ExtConComp, the adversary $\mathcal{A}_{\delta}$ must determine the secret bit $b . \mathcal{A}_{\delta}$ accepts messages in $\{0,1, \top, \perp\}$ and sends the following messages: (a) the message $\left(\mathcal{M}_{\delta}, \top, 0, \delta, g\right)^{2}$, which is a pair of identical creation queries requesting the creation of $\mathcal{M}_{\delta}$, and (b) messages of the form $\left(\left(b_{0}, j\right),\left(b_{1}, j\right)\right)$, where $b_{0}, b_{1} \in\{0,1\}$ and $j \in \mathbb{N}$.
$\mathcal{A}_{\delta}$ starts the communication by sending $\left(\mathcal{M}_{\delta}, \top, 0, \delta, g\right)^{2}$ and setting its state $s=1$. While receiving $T$ as a response, it increments $s$ and alternates its queries:

- If $s$ is odd, it sends $\left(\mathcal{M}_{\delta}, \top, 0, \delta, g\right)^{2}$.
- If $s$ is even, it sends $((0, s / 2),(0, s / 2))$.

In this iterative procedure, $\mathcal{A}_{\delta}$ keeps creating a new instance of $\mathcal{M}_{\delta}$ and asking the query pair $(0,0)$ from it until one instance returns $\perp$. Since ExtConComp always returns $T$ when creating a mechanism, this loop stops upon receiving a respond to $((0, s / 2),(0, s / 2))$.

Once $\mathcal{A}_{\delta}$ receives $\perp$, without increasing $s$, it sends $((0, s / 2),(1, s / 2))$. That is, $\mathcal{A}_{\delta}$ asks the pair $(0,1)$ from the last created instance of $\mathcal{M}_{\delta}$, which has returned $\perp$. If the initial state of the identifier $\mathcal{I}$ in $\mathcal{V}\left[f^{0, \delta}\right] \circ^{*} \mathcal{I} \circ^{*}$ ExtConComp is $b$, then $\mathcal{M}_{\delta}$ receives the query $b$, and by definition it will return $b$ as output, revealing the secret bit $b$.

Therefore, with probability $1-(1-\delta)^{t}$, the adversary $\mathcal{A}_{\delta}$ can detect the secret bit $b$ by sending at most $2 t+1$ queries. Since $\delta>0$, as $t$ goes to infinity, this probability tends to 1 .
5.3. Composition Theorem for Restricted Verification Functions. In Section 5.2, we showed that for any positive $\delta$, the concurrent 1-sparse parallel composition of CMs with the privacy parameter $(0, \delta)$ fails to preserve privacy. In our counterexample, the adversary leveraged the first outcome of a $(0, \delta)$-DP CM to decide whether to spend its budget on issuing non-identical queries to that mechanism. Intuitively, when $\delta>0$, there might exist certain "bad first answers" that occur with low probability; however, once we condition on their occurrences, the distribution of the second answer ceases to be differentially private.

In this section, we force the adversary to decide whether it will always issue pairs of identical queries to a CM when it sends the first message to that mechanism. Specifically, if the first message sent to a CM includes identical queries, then all subsequent messages for that CM must also have identical queries. This leads to the following definition.
Definition 5.3 (First-Pair Consistent). A verification function $f$ is first-pair consistent if the following holds: given an input message sequence $m_{1}, \ldots, m_{t}, f$ returns $\perp$ if $m_{1}$ is a pair of identical messages, i.e., $m_{1}=\left(m^{\prime}, m^{\prime}\right)$ for some $m^{\prime}$, while there exists $2 \leq j \leq t$ such that $m_{j}$ is not a pair of identical messages.

For instance, let $\mathcal{M}$ be an IM that is $(\epsilon, \delta)$-DP w.r.t. a neighbor relation $\sim$. As discussed in Section 3.1, $\mathcal{M}$ can be represented by a $\mathrm{CM} \mathcal{M}^{\prime}$ (with initial state null) that receives an initial state $s \in S_{\mathcal{M}}^{\text {init }}$ as the first message and behaves the same as $\mathcal{M}(s)$ afterwards. Define the verification function $f_{\sim}$ as follows: given an input message sequence $\left(m_{1}, \ldots, m_{t}\right), f_{\sim}$ returns $T$ if and only if $m_{1}$ is a pair of neighboring initial states in $S_{\mathcal{M}}^{\text {init }}$, and for all $2 \leq j \leq t, m_{j}$ is a pair of identical queries in $Q_{\mathcal{M}}$. By definition, $f_{\sim}$ is first-pair consistent.

To formally define the restricted variant of the concurrent parallel composition of CMs, we introduce the verification function $f_{\infty, F P C}^{\epsilon_{1}, \delta_{1}, \ldots, \epsilon_{k}, \delta_{k}}$, where $F P C$ stands for first-pair consistency.
Definition 5.4 $\left(f_{\infty, F P C}^{\epsilon_{1}, \delta_{1}, \ldots, \epsilon_{k}, \delta_{k}}\right)$. For any input message sequence $m_{1}, \ldots, m_{t}$, the function $f_{\infty, F P C}^{\epsilon_{1}, \delta_{1}, \ldots, \epsilon_{k}, \delta_{k}}$ returns $T$ if and only if both of the following conditions hold:
(i) $f_{\infty}^{\epsilon_{1}, \delta_{1}, \ldots, \epsilon_{k}, \delta_{k}}\left(m_{1}, \ldots, m_{t}\right)=\top$

(ii) For every message $m_{j}$ of the form $\left(\mathcal{M}^{\prime}, s^{\prime}, \epsilon^{\prime}, \delta^{\prime}, f^{\prime}\right)^{2}$, the verification function $f^{\prime}$ is first-pair consistent.

We refer to the $f_{\infty, F P C}^{\epsilon_{1}, \delta_{1}, \ldots, \epsilon_{k}, \delta_{k}}$-concurrent composition of CMs as the FPC concurrent $k$-sparse parallel composition of CMs with privacy parameters $\left(\left(\epsilon_{i}, \delta_{i}\right)_{i=1}^{k}\right.$.
Theorem 5.5. For $\epsilon, \epsilon_{1}, \ldots, \epsilon_{k} \geq 0$ and $0 \leq \delta, \delta_{1}, \ldots, \delta_{k} \leq 1$, if the composition of non-interactive mechanisms $\mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon_{1}, \delta_{1}}, \ldots, \mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon_{k}, \delta_{k}}$ is $(\epsilon, \delta)$-DP, then the FPC concurrent $k$-sparse parallel composition of CMs with the privacy parameters $\left(\epsilon_{1}, 0\right), \ldots,\left(\epsilon_{k}, 0\right)$ is also $(\epsilon, \delta)$-DP against an adaptive adversary.
Proof. We denote $f$ as shorthand for $f_{\infty, F P C}^{\epsilon_{1}, \delta_{1}, \ldots, \epsilon_{k}, \delta_{k}}$. This proof is identical to the proof of Theorem 5.2, except for the following modification in the definition of $\mathcal{P}$ : In the proof of Theorem 5.2, each $\mathcal{T}_{j}$ behaved identically to $\mathcal{V}\left[f_{j}^{\prime}\right] \circ^{*} \mathcal{I}(0) \circ^{*} \mathcal{M}_{j}^{\prime}$ if $\delta_{j}^{\prime}>0$ and was defined according to Lemma 4.7 otherwise. In this proof, each $\mathcal{T}_{j}$ behaves identically to $\mathcal{V}\left[f_{j}^{\prime}\right] \circ^{*} \mathcal{I}(0) \circ^{*} \mathcal{M}_{j}^{\prime}$ if the first message of the form $\left(\left(q_{0}, j\right),\left(q_{1}, j\right)\right)$ satisfies $q_{0}=q_{1}$, and it is defined by Lemma 4.6 otherwise.

To implement this, $\mathcal{P}$ 's state must include an additional sequence $\sigma_{3}$, storing a flag for each created mechanism, indicating whether the mechanism has previously received any messages. When $\mathcal{P}$ receives the creation query pair $\left(\mathcal{M}_{j}^{\prime}, s_{j}^{\prime}, \epsilon_{j}^{\prime}, \delta_{j}^{\prime}, f_{j}^{\prime}\right)^{2}$ from the verifier, it adds the pair $\left(\mathcal{M}_{j}^{\prime}, s_{j}^{\prime}\right)$ to $\sigma_{2}$, appends a 0 to the end of $\sigma_{3}$, and returns $\top$.

Upon receiving a message of the form $\left(\left(q_{0}, j\right),\left(q_{1}, j\right)\right)$, if the $j$-th element of $\sigma_{3}$ is $0, \mathcal{P}$ sets this element to 1 and replaces the entry $\left(\mathcal{M}_{j}^{\prime}, s_{j}^{\prime}\right)$ in $\sigma_{2}$ with $\left(\mathcal{T}_{j}, t_{j}\right)$, defined as follows:

- If $q_{0}=q_{1}$, then $\mathcal{T}_{j}$ is an IPM with the single initial state $s_{j}^{\prime}$ that never interacts with its right mechanism and interacts with its left mechanism exactly as $\mathcal{V}\left[f_{j}^{\prime}\right] \circ^{*} \mathcal{I}(0) \circ^{*} \mathcal{M}_{j}^{\prime}$.
- If $q_{0} \neq q_{1}$, then $\mathcal{T}_{j}$ is the IPM defined by Lemma 4.6 corresponding to $\mathcal{M}_{j}^{\prime}$.
$\mathcal{T}_{j}$ with the first definition never requires a sample from $\mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon_{j}^{\prime}, \delta_{j}^{\prime}}$, while a $\mathcal{T}_{j}$ with the second definition may require at most one sample (see Remark 4.8). We will show that the privacy parameters $\left(\epsilon_{j}^{\prime}, \delta_{j}^{\prime}\right)$ corresponding to $\mathcal{T}_{j} \mathrm{~s}$ with the second definition form a sub-multiset of $\left(\epsilon_{1}, \delta_{1}\right), \ldots,\left(\epsilon_{k}, \delta_{k}\right)$ :

By Definition 5.4 (ii), we know that for each index $j$, if $q_{0}=q_{1}$ in the first message of the form $\left((q_{0}, j),\left(q_{1}, j\right)\right)$, then $q_{0}=q_{1}$ in all subsequent messages of this form. Thus, by Definition 5.4 (i) and Definition 5.1 (ii), the privacy parameters $\left(\epsilon_{j}^{\prime}, \delta_{j}^{\prime}\right)$ corresponding to $\mathcal{T}_{j} \mathrm{~s}$ with the second definition (which receive at least one pair of non-identical queries) form a sub-multiset of $\left(\epsilon_{1}, \delta_{1}\right), \ldots,\left(\epsilon_{k}, \delta_{k}\right)$.
5.3.1. Concurrent $k$-sparse Parallel Composition of IM. Consider a setting where an adversary creates (an unlimited number of) IMs over time while adaptively asking queries from the existing ones. When creating an IM $\mathcal{M}_{i}$ that is $\left(\epsilon_{i}, \delta_{i}\right)$-DP w.r.t. a neighbor relation $\sim_{i}$, the adversary also selects a pair of neighboring initial states for $\mathcal{M}_{i}$. This selection depends on the history of queries asked so far and their responses. Based on a secret bit $b$, either all created mechanisms are initialized with the first initial state in their respective pairs, or all are initialized with the second. The goal of the adversary is to guess $b$.

This scenario is an special case of FPC concurrent $k$-sparse parallel composition of CMs, where, instead of creating $\mathcal{M}_{i}$ and assigning a pair of initial states to it, the adversary sends $\left(\mathcal{M}_{i}^{\prime}\right.$, null, $\left.\epsilon_{i}, \delta_{i}, f_{\sim_{i}}\right)^{2}$, where $\mathcal{M}_{i}^{\prime}$ is the CM simulating $\mathcal{M}_{i}$. Moreover, to ask a query $q$ from the $i$-th created IM, the adversary sends $((q, i),(q, i))$. Since each $f_{\sim_{i}}$ is first-pair consistent, Theorem 5.5 applies to the concurrent $k$-sparse parallel composition of IM with privacy parameters $\left(\left(\epsilon_{i}, \delta_{i}\right)_{i=1}^{k}\right.$ (that are differentially private w.r.t. neighbor relations).

NIMs are a special subclass of IMs that halt the communication upon receiving a second input message. Since Theorem 5.5 applies to all IMs, it also holds for the concurrent $k$-sparse parallel composition of NIMs with privacy parameters $\left(\left(\epsilon_{1}, \delta_{i}\right)_{i=1}^{k}\right.$. In the next section, we compare this result to the classical parallel composition theorem.

5.3.2. Comparison with the Parallel Composition of NIMs. Consider a set of $\ell$ NIMs, $\mathcal{N}_{1}, \ldots, \mathcal{N}_{\ell}$, where each $\mathcal{N}_{i}$ has a domain $\mathcal{X}_{i}$ and is $\left(\epsilon_{i}, \delta_{i}\right)$-DP w.r.t. a neighbor relation $\sim_{i}$. The $k$-sparse parallel composition of NIMs $\mathcal{N}_{1}, \ldots, \mathcal{N}_{\ell}$ is said to be $(\epsilon, \delta)$-DP if the non-interactive mechanism $\operatorname{Comp}\left(\mathcal{N}_{1}, \ldots, \mathcal{N}_{\ell}\right)$ with the domain $\mathcal{X}=\mathcal{X}_{1} \times \cdots \times \mathcal{X}_{\ell}$ is $(\epsilon, \delta)$-DP w.r.t. the neighbor relation $\sim_{\text {par }}$, defined as follows: for any two $x=\left(x_{1}, \ldots x_{\ell}\right)$ and $x^{\prime}=\left(x_{1}^{\prime}, \ldots x_{\ell}^{\prime}\right)$ in $\mathcal{X}$, we have $x \sim_{\text {par }} x^{\prime}$ if and only if there exists a subset $\mathcal{J} \subseteq\{1, \ldots, \ell\}$ of size at most $k$ such that $x_{j} \sim_{j} x_{j}^{\prime}$ for every $j \in \mathcal{J}$, and $x_{j}=x_{j}^{\prime}$ for every $j \in\{1, \ldots, \ell\} \backslash \mathcal{J}$.

The concurrent parallel composition of IMs generalizes the parallel composition of NIMs in several key ways: Rather than composing a fixed set of $\ell$ NIMs, an adversary adaptively selects an unbounded number of IMs with arbitrary privacy parameters. Additionally, instead of non-adaptively selecting worst-case neighboring initial states for (at most) $k$ mechanisms and identical initial states for the other $\ell-k$ mechanisms, the adversary adaptively (1) chooses pairs of initial states based on prior interactions with other mechanisms, while (2) ensuring that the initial states in at most $k$ pairs are neighboring, and that they are identical in the other pairs. In the concurrent parallel composition of CMs, the adversary is even stronger: instead of choosing a single pair of neighboring initial states, it adaptively selects a sequence of pairs, satisfying the constraints enforced by a verification function.

The 1-sparse parallel composition of NIMs is commonly used when a dataset is partitioned among $\ell$ NIMs such that for any two neighboring datasets differing by a single record, all partitions remain identical except for the presence of the differing record in one partition. Consider the case where an adversary creates CMs receiving data or empty records as query messages. In the concurrent parallel composition of CMs , the adversary adaptively determines the number of partitions, assigns records to them, and selects which partitions contain differing sets of records.

It is known that the $k$-sparse parallel composition of $\ell\left(\epsilon_{0}, \delta_{0}\right)$-DP NIMs is $(\epsilon, \delta)$-DP if the composition of $\ell$ instances of $\mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon_{0}, \delta_{0}}$ is $(\epsilon, \delta)$-DP. We showed that any NIM that is $\left(\epsilon_{0}, \delta_{0}\right)$-DP w.r.t. a neighbor relation $\sim$ can be modeled by a CM that is $\left(\epsilon_{0}, \delta_{0}\right)$-DP w.r.t. $f_{\sim}$, which is a first-pair consistent verification function. Thus, setting $\epsilon_{1}=\cdots=\epsilon_{k}=\epsilon_{0}, \delta_{1}=\cdots=\delta_{k}=\delta_{0}$ in Theorem 5.5 recovers and generalizes the classic parallel composition theorem. Our theorem extends differential privacy guarantees to settings where an adversary can adaptively create an unbounded number of NIMs.

# 6. Designing Complex Continual Mechanisms 

So far we discussed the setting where the messages are issued by an adversary. However, in the design of differentially private mechanisms in the streaming setting, it is common to use existing differentially private interactive mechanisms, such as the Sparse Vector Technique (SVT) and continual counters, as sub-mechanisms. Thus, it is the main mechanism $\mathcal{M}$ that issues messages to its sub-mechanisms. The main mechanism may fix the set of sub-mechanisms at initialization or select these mechanisms adaptively over time. For example, in Section 7, we present a mechanism that maintains $d$ fixed binary counters while adaptively instantiating an unbounded number of SVT and Laplace mechanisms as required.

The privacy analysis of such mechanisms $\mathcal{M}$ is challenging as the creation of sub-mechanisms and their inputs is adaptive and dependent. The goal of this section is to give a set of conditions for $\mathcal{M}$ and prove a theorem that shows that under these conditions the privacy of $\mathcal{M}$ can directly be computed by applying the known concurrent composition theorems for continual mechanisms to the sub-mechanisms. Specifically, given that the $f^{\prime}$-concurrent composition of CMs is $(\epsilon, \delta)$-DP w.r.t. some verification function $f^{\prime}$, we would like to show that $\mathcal{M}$ is $(\epsilon, \delta)$-DP w.r.t. the given verification function $f$.

As discussed in Section 3, these sub-mechanisms can be modeled as CMs. We formalize $\mathcal{M}$, which runs multiple CMs, as a continual mechanism of the form $\mathcal{P} \circ^{*} \operatorname{ExtConComp}$, where $\mathcal{P}$ is an IPM and ExtConComp is the CM defined in Section 4.1. Since $\mathcal{M}$ is a CM, its initial state space is a

singleton, implying that the initial state space of $\mathcal{P}$ is also a singleton. Upon receiving a message, $\mathcal{P}$ may create new differentially private CMs or ask queries from the existing ones by communicating with ExtConComp, possibly multiple times.

To prove that $\mathcal{M}$ is $(\epsilon, \delta)$-DP w.r.t. $f$, we need to show that the view of every adversary $\mathcal{A}$ interacting with $\mathcal{V}[f] \circ^{*} \mathcal{I}(0) \circ^{*} \mathcal{M}=\mathcal{V}[f] \circ^{*} \mathcal{I}(0) \circ^{*} \mathcal{P} \circ^{*}$ ExtConComp and $\mathcal{V}[f] \circ^{*} \mathcal{I}(1) \circ^{*} \mathcal{M}=\mathcal{V}[f] \circ^{*}$ $\mathcal{I}(1) \circ^{*} \mathcal{P} \circ^{*}$ ExtConComp is $(\epsilon, \delta)$-indistinguishable. Intuitively, the messages that $\mathcal{P} \circ^{*}$ ExtConComp receives from $\mathcal{I}(b)$ contains information about $b$. Therefore, to deduce that $\mathcal{P} \circ^{*}$ ExtConComp is $(\epsilon, \delta)$-DP w.r.t. $f$ from the fact that ExtConComp is $(\epsilon, \delta)$-DP w.r.t. $f^{\prime}$, the IPM $\mathcal{P}$ must not directly use the messages from $\mathcal{I}$ to respond. Instead, it should only use these messages to determine which queries it wants to send to its its sub-mechanisms via ExtConComp. More precisely, $\mathcal{P}$ must generate an answer for $\mathcal{I}$ only based on the privatized answers provided by ExtConComp and not dependent on the un-privatized input sequence (Response Property). Moreover, $\mathcal{P}$ must decide whether to continue interacting with ExtConComp or to return a response based on these privatized answers (Destination Property).

Finally, we need a property for $\mathcal{P}$ to convert $f$-valid message sequences to $f^{\prime}$-valid ones: Let $m_{1}^{0}, m_{2}^{0}, \ldots$ and $m_{1}^{1}, m_{2}^{1}, \ldots$ be two sequences such that the sequence $\left(m_{1}^{0}, m_{1}^{1}\right),\left(m_{2}^{0}, m_{2}^{1}\right), \ldots$ is $f$-valid. Upon receiving each sequence $m_{1}^{h}, m_{2}^{h}, \ldots$, the mechanism $\mathcal{P}$ must send the messages $m_{1}^{h^{\prime}}, m_{2}^{h^{\prime}}, \ldots$ to ExtConComp such that $\left(m_{1}^{0^{\prime}}, m_{1}^{1^{\prime}}\right),\left(m_{2}^{0^{\prime}}, m_{2}^{1^{\prime}}\right), \ldots$ is $f^{\prime}$-valid ( $f \rightarrow f^{\prime}$ Property).

In Section 6.1, we formalize the above properties for $\mathcal{P}$, and in Section 6.2, we prove the desired privacy guarantees for $\mathcal{M}$. Combining this result with the concurrent composition theorems provided in the previous sections, we can avoid complicated privacy analysis for many CMs.
6.1. Properties. To formally state that $\mathcal{P}$ maps $f$-valid sequences to $f^{\prime}$-valid ones, we assume that $\mathcal{P}$ is deterministic. This means $\mathcal{P}$ can be expressed as a deterministic function that maps the sequence of received messages to its next output message. This assumption is not restrictive, as randomness can be modeled by a 0 -DP sub-mechanism $\mathcal{M}_{i}$ that accepts a single message $\top$, and upon receiving it, generates a sufficiently long sequence of random bits or samples from a fixed distribution.

Recall that the goal of this section is to show $\mathcal{P} \circ^{*}$ ExtConComp is $(\epsilon, \delta)$-DP w.r.t. $f^{\prime}$ if ExtConComp is $(\epsilon, \delta)$-DP w.r.t. $f$. That is, we need to show that the view of any adversary in the interactions with $\mathcal{V}[f] \circ^{*} \mathcal{I}(0) \circ^{*} \mathcal{P} \circ^{*}$ ExtConComp and $\mathcal{V}[f] \circ^{*} \mathcal{I}(1) \circ^{*} \mathcal{P} \circ^{*}$ ExtConComp is $(\epsilon, \delta)$-indistinguishable.

The messages received by $\mathcal{P}$ from $\mathcal{I}$ contain information about the bit used by $\mathcal{I}$ to filter the adversary's pairs. Therefore, to directly use the existing compositions theorems for ExtConComp to analyze the privacy of $\mathcal{P} \circ^{*}$ ExtConComp, we need to ensure that $\mathcal{P}$ only utilizes the messages from $\mathcal{I}$ to generate queries for the existing private sub-mechanisms executed by ExtConComp. Moreover, we need to guarantee that the sequence $\left(m_{1}^{0^{\prime}}, m_{1}^{1^{\prime}}\right),\left(m_{2}^{0^{\prime}}, m_{2}^{1^{\prime}}\right), \ldots$ is $f^{\prime}$-valid, where $m_{1}^{b^{\prime}}, m_{2}^{b^{\prime}}, \ldots$ is the sequence of messages that $\mathcal{P}$ sends to ExtConComp when it receives messages from $\mathcal{I}(b) \circ^{*} \mathcal{V}[f]$. The following properties formalize these:

- Destination Property. The destination L or R of messages sent by $\mathcal{P}$ is determined solely based on messages received from its right mechanism (here, ExtConComp). This ensures that if two transcripts contain identical sequences of messages from the right mechanism but different sequences from the left mechanism, $\mathcal{P}$ will still interact with the same mechanism in the next round.
- Response Property. The responses sent by $\mathcal{P}$ to the left mechanism depend only on the messages received from the right mechanism. That is, if two transcripts contain identical sequences of messages from the right mechanism and $\mathcal{P}$ sends its next message to the left mechanism, then this message is identical in both cases.
- $f \rightarrow f^{\prime}$ Property. For $v \in\{\mathrm{~L}, \mathrm{R}\}$, let the pair $(m, v)$ denote a message $m$ sent to or received from the left or right mechanism of $\mathcal{P}$. For $b \in\{0,1\}$, let $\sigma^{b}=\left(\left(m_{1}^{b}, v_{1}^{b}\right), \ldots,\left(m_{t}^{b}, v_{t}^{b}\right)\right)$ be a sequence of

$t$ input messages to $\mathcal{P}$, and let $\tau^{b}=\left(\left(m_{1}^{b t}, v_{1}^{b t}\right), \ldots,\left(m_{t}^{b t}, v_{t}^{b t}\right)\right)$ be the corresponding sequence of $t$ output messages from $\mathcal{P}$. Suppose the following conditions hold:
(i) $v_{i}^{0}=v_{i}^{1}$ for each $i \in[t]$, i.e., the sender of messages is identical;
(ii) $m_{i}^{0}=m_{i}^{1}$ for each $i \in[t]$ where $v_{i}^{0}=v_{i}^{1}=\mathrm{R}$, meaning that messages from the right mechanism are identical; and
(iii) the sequence of $\left(m_{i}^{0}, m_{i}^{1}\right)$ s for all $i \in[t]$ where $v_{i}^{0}=v_{i}^{1}=\mathrm{L}$ is $f$-valid.

Then, by the destination property of $\mathcal{P}, v_{i}^{0 t}=v_{i}^{1 t}$ for each $i \in[t]$, and by the response property, $m_{i}^{0 t}=m_{i}^{1 t}$ for each $i \in[t]$ with $v_{i}^{0}=v_{i}^{1}=\mathrm{L}$. The $f \rightarrow f^{\prime}$ property states that under these conditions, the sequence $\left(\left(m_{i}^{0 t}, m_{i}^{1 t}\right)\right)$ for all $i \in[t]$ where $v_{i}^{0 t}=v_{i}^{1 t}=\mathrm{R}$ must be $f^{\prime}$-valid.
6.2. Privacy Result. In this section, we will prove the following theorem:

Theorem 6.1. Let $\mathcal{P}$ be a deterministic interactive post-processing mechanism with a singleton initial state space satisfying the destination, response, and $f \rightarrow f^{\prime}$ properties. If ExtConComp is $(\epsilon, \delta)$-DP w.r.t. $f^{\prime}$ against adaptive adversaries, then the continual mechanism $\mathcal{P} \circ^{*}$ ExtConComp is $(\epsilon, \delta)$-DP w.r.t. $f$ against adaptive adversaries.

In Theorem 6.1, we assume that the view of any adversary interacting with $\mathcal{V}\left[f^{\prime}\right] \circ^{*} \mathcal{I}(0) \circ^{*}$ ExtConComp and $\mathcal{V}\left[f^{\prime}\right] \circ^{*} \mathcal{I}(1) \circ^{*}$ ExtConComp is $(\epsilon, \delta)$-indistinguishable. The goal is to show the same result for $\mathcal{V}[f] \circ^{*} \mathcal{I}(0) \circ^{*} \mathcal{P} \circ^{*}$ ExtConComp and $\mathcal{V}[f] \circ^{*} \mathcal{I}(1) \circ^{*} \mathcal{P} \circ^{*}$ ExtConComp. The key idea of the proof is to show that the IMs $\mathcal{V}[f] \circ^{*} \mathcal{I}(b) \circ^{*} \mathcal{P} \circ^{*}$ ExtConComp and $\mathcal{T} \circ^{*} \mathcal{V}\left[f^{\prime}\right] \circ^{*} \mathcal{I}(b) \circ^{*}$ ExtConComp are identical, where $\mathcal{T}$ is an IPM with a singleton initial state space. The proof consists of two steps.

Step 1 (Swapping $\mathcal{P}$ and $\mathcal{I}(b)$ ). We start by swapping the positions of $\mathcal{P}$ and $\mathcal{I}(b)$ in $\mathcal{V}[f] \circ^{*} \mathcal{I}(b) \circ^{*}$ $\mathcal{P} \circ^{*}$ ExtConComp. The verifier $\mathcal{V}[f]$ sends pairs of query messages, while $\mathcal{P}$ expects a single one. Also, the identifier $\mathcal{I}(b)$ expects pairs of messages, while $\mathcal{P}$ generates a single response. Therefore, when swapping $\mathcal{P}$ and $\mathcal{I}(b)$, we should replace $\mathcal{P} \circ^{*} \mathcal{I}(b)$ with $\mathcal{I}(b) \circ^{*} \mathcal{P}^{2}$, where $\mathcal{P}^{2}$ is an interactive post-processing mechanism that runs two instances of $\mathcal{P}$ in parallel. The right mechanism of $\mathcal{P}^{2}$ is $\mathcal{I} \circ^{*}$ ExtConComp, and its left mechanism is $\mathcal{V}[f]$. The exact definition of $\mathcal{P}^{2}$ is given below.
Definition 6.2 $\left(\mathcal{P}^{2}\right)$. Let $\mathcal{P}: S_{\mathcal{P}} \times\left(\left(\{L\} \times Q_{\mathcal{P}}^{L}\right) \cup\left(\{\bar{R}\} \times Q_{\mathcal{P}}^{R}\right)\right) \rightarrow S_{\mathcal{P}} \times\left(\left(\{L\} \times A_{\mathcal{P}}^{L}\right) \cup\left(\{\bar{R}\} \times A_{\mathcal{P}}^{R}\right)\right)$ be a deterministic interactive post-processing mechanism with a singleton initial state space $S_{\mathcal{P}}^{\text {init }}=\left\{s^{\text {init }}\right\}$, satisfying the destination and response properties. $\mathcal{P}^{2}: S_{\mathcal{P}}^{2} \times$ $\left(\left(\{L\} \times Q_{\mathcal{P}}^{L}\right) \cup\left(\{\bar{R}\} \times Q_{\mathcal{P}}^{R} \times Q_{\mathcal{P}}^{R}\right)\right) \rightarrow S_{\mathcal{P}} \times\left(\left(\{L\} \times A_{\mathcal{P}}^{L}\right) \cup\left(\{\bar{R}\} \times A_{\mathcal{P}}^{R}\right)\right)$ is an interactive postprocessing mechanism that executes two instances of $\mathcal{P}$, referred to as $\mathcal{P}_{0}$ and $\mathcal{P}_{1}$. The state of $\mathcal{P}^{2}$ is a pair $\left(s_{0}, s_{1}\right)$ denoting the current states of $\mathcal{P}_{0}$ and $\mathcal{P}_{1}$. The initial state space of $\mathcal{P}^{2}$ is $\left\{\left(s^{\text {init }}, s^{\text {init }}\right)\right\}$.

When $\mathcal{P}^{2}$ receives a message $m \in Q_{\mathcal{P}}^{L}$ from the left mechanism, it forwards two copies of $m$ to both $\mathcal{P}_{0}$ and $\mathcal{P}_{1}$ as left messages. Specifically, it executes $\left(s_{0}, v_{0}, m_{0}^{\prime}\right) \leftarrow \mathcal{P}_{0}\left(s_{0}, L, m\right)$ and $\left(s_{1}, v_{1}, m_{1}^{\prime}\right) \leftarrow$ $\mathcal{P}_{1}\left(s_{1}, L, m\right)$. When $\mathcal{P}^{2}$ receives a pair of messages $\left(m_{0}, m_{1}\right) \in Q_{\mathcal{P}}^{R} \times Q_{\mathcal{P}}^{R}$ from the right mechanism, it passes each $m_{b}$ to $\mathcal{P}_{b}$ as a right message. Specifically, it executes $\left(s_{0}, v_{0}, m_{0}^{\prime}\right) \leftarrow \mathcal{P}_{0}\left(s_{0}, R, m_{0}\right)$ and $\left(s_{1}, v_{1}, m_{1}^{\prime}\right) \leftarrow \mathcal{P}_{1}\left(s_{1}, R, m_{0}\right)$. By the destination property of $\mathcal{P}$ and the fact that both $\mathcal{P}_{0}$ and $\mathcal{P}_{1}$ receive identical left messages, we have $v_{0}^{\prime}=v_{1}^{\prime}$. If $v_{0}^{\prime}=v_{1}^{\prime}=R$, then $\mathcal{P}^{2}$ sends $\left(m_{0}^{\prime}, m_{1}^{\prime}\right)$ to its right mechanism. If $v_{0}^{\prime}=v_{1}^{\prime}=L$, then by the response property, $m_{0}^{\prime}=m_{1}^{\prime}$, and $\mathcal{P}^{2}$ returns $m_{0}^{\prime}$ to its left mechanism.

The following claim follow directly from the definition of $\mathcal{P}^{2}$ :
Claim 6.3. For each $b \in\{0,1\}$, the interactive mechanisms $\mathcal{I}(b) \circ^{*} \mathcal{P} \circ^{*}$ ExtConComp and $\mathcal{P}^{2} \circ^{*}$ $\mathcal{I}(b) \circ^{*}$ ExtConComp are identical.
Step 2 (Inserting $\mathcal{V}\left[f^{\prime}\right]$ ). Due to the $f \rightarrow f^{\prime}$ property, when $\mathcal{P}^{2}$ receives an $f$-valid message sequence from its left mechanism, it sends an $f^{\prime}$-valid message sequence to its right mechanism. We insert $\mathcal{V}\left[f^{\prime}\right]$ between $\mathcal{P}^{2}$ and $\mathcal{I}$ in $\mathcal{P}^{2} \circ^{*} \mathcal{I} \circ^{*}$ ExtConComp. By definition, when $\mathcal{V}\left[f^{\prime}\right]$ receives an $f^{\prime}$-valid

message sequence from its left mechanism, it acts like it does not exist. Specifically, it forwards every message from its left and right mechanism unchanged to the opposite mechanism. Thus, we have:

Claim 6.4. For each $b \in\{0,1\}$, the interactive mechanisms $\mathcal{V}[f] \circ^{*} \mathcal{P}^{2} \circ^{*} \mathcal{I}(b) \circ^{*}$ ExtConComp and $\mathcal{V}[f] \circ^{*} \mathcal{P}^{2} \circ^{*} \mathcal{V}[f^{\prime}] \circ^{*} \mathcal{I}(b) \circ^{*}$ ExtConComp are identical.
proof of Theorem 6.1. $\mathcal{V}[f] \circ^{*} \mathcal{P}^{2}$ in Claim 6.4 is an IPM with a singleton initial state space. Thus, by Lemma 2.15 , that $\mathcal{V}\left[f^{\prime}\right] \circ^{*} \mathcal{I} \circ^{*}$ ExtConComp, is $(\epsilon, \delta)$-DP w.r.t. $\sim_{01}$ implies the view of any adversary in the interactions with $\mathcal{V}[f] \circ^{*} \mathcal{I}(0) \circ^{*} \mathcal{P} \circ^{*}$ ExtConComp and $\mathcal{V}[f] \circ^{*} \mathcal{I}(1) \circ^{*} \mathcal{P} \circ^{*}$ ExtConComp is $(\epsilon, \delta)$-indistinguishable, which finishes the proof.

# 7. Application (Continual Monotone Histogram Query Problem) 

We next show an application of our technique to the continual monotone histogram query problem. The continual monotone histogram query problem is defined as follows.

Definition 7.1. Let $d \in \mathbb{N}$ and let $q: \mathbb{N}^{d} \rightarrow \mathbb{N}$ be a function that is monotone in its input. The input is a finite stream of row vectors $x^{1}, \ldots, x^{T}$ with $x^{t} \in\{0,1\}^{d}$ for all $t \in[T]$. Let $\sim$ be a neighbor relation on $\left(\{0,1\}^{d}\right)^{*}$ where two input streams are neighboring if they are identical except for a single step. The output of the (differentially private) continual monotone histogram query problem at each time step $t$ is (an additive approximation to) $q(t)=q\left(\left(\sum_{\ell=1}^{t} x_{i}^{\ell}\right)_{i \in[d]}\right)$.

Next we define query sensitivity.
Definition 7.2. The function $q:\{0,1\}^{d} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ is 1-sensitive if $\max _{x \sim y}|q(x)-q(y)|$ is at most 1 .
Henzinger, Sricharan, and Steiner [12] presented the best known differentially private mechanism for the monotone histogram query problem, where where the query is 1-sensitive. For $\epsilon$-differential privacy it has, with probability at least $1-\beta$, an additive error of $O\left(\left(d \log ^{2}\left(d q^{*} / \beta\right)+\log T\right) \epsilon^{-1}\right)$, and for $(\epsilon, \delta)$-differential privacy, it has an additive error of $O\left(\left(d \log ^{1.5}\left(d q^{*} / \beta\right)+\log T\right) \epsilon^{-1} \log \frac{1}{\delta}\right)$, where $q^{*}=\max _{t \in[T]} q(t)$. The privacy of the mechanism is proven "from scratch" using the concept of a privacy game [13] and the latter bound only holds against an oblivious adversary.

In Section 7.1, we give an overview of the mechanism in [12], which we will call HSS, and in Section 7.2, we give a simple privacy proof for it using our approach. With the new privacy analysis, the result for $(\epsilon, \delta)$-differential privacy is stronger and holds against an adaptive adversary.
7.1. Overview of Mechanism. The mechanism HSS, described in Algorithm 4, employs a variant of the Sparse Vector Technique (SVT) defined by two operations. The first, SVT-init $(\epsilon, q, h)$, initializes the mechanism with the privacy parameter $\epsilon$, the histogram query $q$, and an initial $d$-dimensional vector $h$. The second operation, SVT-call $\left(x^{(t)}\right.$, Thresh), processes an input value $x^{(t)} \in\{0,1\}^{d}$ along with a threshold Thresh. This algorithm maintains a running sum of all the first parameters from SVT-call and tests in a private manner whether the function $q$ applied to the running sum returns a value that is at least Thresh. If so the algorithm returns $\top$ and does not accept any further calls. Otherwise it returns $\perp$ and continues to accept calls. These two algorithms are given in detail in Algorithm 3. The command Lap(b) means that a random value from the Laplacian distribution with parameter $b$ is returned.

The algorithms SVT-init and SVT-call describe a continual mechanism SVT with state $(h, \epsilon, q, \tau)$ that maps input queries in $\{0,1\}^{d}$ to answers in $\{\top, \perp\}$. In our language, whenever HSS calls SVT-init $(\epsilon / 6, q, h)$, a continual mechanism $\mathrm{SVT}_{\epsilon / 6, q, h}$ with the single initial state $(\epsilon / 6, q, h, \tau=$ null) is created. Upon receiving the first input message (i.e., when $\tau=$ null), $\mathrm{SVT}_{\epsilon / 6, q, h}$ sets null to a sample from $\operatorname{Lap}(6 / \epsilon)$. Then, according to the algorithm SVT-call, it updates the state and returns an output. Receiving the subsequent queries, $\tau \neq$ null, and $\mathrm{SVT}_{\epsilon / 6, q, h}$ simply updates the variables and generates an output.

```
Algorithm 3 Sparse vector technique for histogram queries
    procedure \(\operatorname{SVT}-\operatorname{INIT}(\epsilon, q, h)\) :
        \(h_{i} \leftarrow h_{i}\) for all \(i \in[d]\)
        \(\epsilon=\epsilon\)
        \(q=q\)
        \(\tau \leftarrow \operatorname{Lap}(1 / \epsilon)\)
    end procedure
    procedure SVT-CALL \((x\), Thresh \()\)
        \(h_{i}=h_{i}+x_{i}\) for all \(i \in[d]\)
        if \(q(h)+\operatorname{Lap}(2 / \epsilon)>\) Thresh \(+\tau\) then
            return \(\top\) and halt
        else
            return \(\perp\)
        end if
    end procedure
```

Let $f_{\sim}$ be a verification function that given a message sequence $m_{1}, \ldots, m_{t}$, returns $\top$ if and only if for each $j \in[t]$, the message $m_{j}$ is of the form $\left(m_{j}^{0}, m_{j}^{1}\right)$ and the message sequences $\sigma_{0}=\left(m_{1}^{0}, \ldots, m_{t}^{0}\right)$ and $\sigma_{1}=\left(m_{1}^{1}, \ldots, m_{t}^{1}\right)$ satisfy $\sigma_{0} \sim \sigma_{1}$. As part of their privacy proof, the following is shown in [12], which we restate in our own language.

Lemma 7.3. If $q$ is a 1-sensitive function, then for every $\epsilon$ and $h$, the mechanism $S V T_{\epsilon / 6, q, h}$ is $\epsilon / 3-D P$ w.r.t. $f_{\sim}$.

For positive integers $t$ and $j, \beta \in(0,1]$, and $\epsilon>0$, let $\gamma(t, j, \beta, \epsilon)$ and $\xi(t, j, \beta, \epsilon)$ are some deterministic functions. Given an input stream $x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots$ with $x_{i} \in\{0,1\}^{d}$, the algorithm partitions the input stream into subsequences, called intervals. At the end of each interval, it gives the $d$-dimensional sum of all the inputs of the interval to a differentially-private histogram mechanism H. Note that H can be used directly to solve the problem; however, the new mechanism HSS has better accuracy bounds in many cases.

H is described by two operations, namely $\mathrm{H}-\mathrm{init}(\epsilon)$ and $\mathrm{H}-\mathrm{add}(x)$, where $x$ is a $d$-dimensional vector. The first initializes $d$ empty differentially private continual binary counters with privacy parameter $\epsilon / d$. The second operation gives each element of the $d$-dimensional vector $x$ to the corresponding binary counter and returns their aggregated outputs as a $d$-dimensional vector. In another version of the algorithm, $\mathrm{H}-\mathrm{init}(\epsilon, \delta)$ initializes $d$ empty differentially private continual binary counters with privacy parameters $\epsilon / d$ and $\delta / d$. In our language, H is a continual mechanism that stores the required variables in its state and upon receiving a query in $\{0,1\}^{d}$, updates its state (i.e., the variables) and returns an answer in $\mathbb{R}^{d}$. The initial state of H is the tuple of initial values for the variables, specified by algorithm H -init.

The continual histogram query mechanism HSS keeps two $d$-dimensional vectors, called $h$ and $c$, namely for each coordinate $i \in\{1,2, \ldots, d\}$ a variable $c_{i}$ and a variable $h_{i}$, where $c_{i}$ keeps the actual sum of column $i$ for the current interval and $h_{i}$ keeps the approximate sum of column $i$ for all inputs before in the current interval as computed by H. Both are initially 0 . The algorithm also keeps at any point an instance of SVT and initializes it with $\epsilon / 6, q$, and $h$. It also initializes Thresh using $\gamma(1,1, \beta, \epsilon)$. On a new input $x^{(t)}$ the algorithm updates $c$ and then calls SVT-call $\left(x^{(t)}\right.$, Thresh $)$ using the threshold Thresh. If it returns $\top$, the algorithm ends the current interval, inputs $c$ to H , sets $h$ to be the output of H , and sets $c$ to the all-zero vector. As SVT has ended, it creates a new instance of SVT with the call SVT-init $(\epsilon / 6, q, h)$. It then applies the Laplacian mechanism to $q(c+h)$ and compares its outcome with a slightly lower threshold Thresh' that is computed using Thresh and $\xi(t, j, \beta, \epsilon)$. If it is larger, Thresh is suitably increased. Independent of the outcome of

this comparison, Thresh is then updated (to reflect the increase in the number of intervals). Finally independent of the output of the call to SVT, $h$ is output and Thresh is again updated (to reflect the increase in the number of input vectors). The algorithm is given in detail in Algorithm 4, the accuracy proof can be found in [12].

```
Algorithm 4 Mechanism for answering a monotone histogram query
    H-init \((\epsilon / 3)\)
    \(h_{i} \leftarrow 0\) for all \(i \in[d], c_{i} \leftarrow 0\) for all \(i \in[d]\)
    out \(\leftarrow q(h)\)
    \(j \leftarrow 1\)
    SVT-init \((\epsilon / 6, q, h)\)
    Thresh \(=\gamma(1, j, \beta, \epsilon)\)
    for \(t \in \mathbb{N}\) do
        \(c_{i} \leftarrow c_{i}+x_{i}^{(t)}\) for all \(i \in[d]\)
        if \(\operatorname{SVT}-\operatorname{call}\left(x^{(t)}\right.\), Thresh \()==\top\) then
            \(h=\mathrm{H}-\mathrm{add}(c)\)
            out \(\leftarrow q(h)\)
            SVT-init \((\epsilon / 6, q, h)\)
            \(c_{i} \leftarrow 0\) for all \(i \in[d]\)
            if \(q(c+h)+\operatorname{Lap}(3 / \epsilon)>\) Thresh \(-\xi(t, j, \beta, \epsilon)\) then
                Thresh \(=\) Thresh \(+\gamma(t, j, \beta, \epsilon)\)
            end if
            \(j \leftarrow j+1\)
            Thresh \(=\) Thresh \(-\gamma(t, j-1, \beta, \epsilon)+\gamma(t, j, \beta, \epsilon)\)
    end if
    output out
    Thresh \(=\) Thresh \(-\gamma(t, j, \beta, \epsilon)+\gamma(t+1, j, \beta, \epsilon)\)
end for
```

7.2. New Privacy Analysis. Algorithm 4 describes a CM HSS with query set $\{0,1\}^{d}$ and answer set $\mathbb{N}^{d}$. The state of HSS consists of the variables ( $h, c, j$, out, Thresh), initialized with $\left(0^{d}, 0^{d}, 1, q\left(0^{d}\right), \gamma(1,1, \beta, \epsilon)\right)$. The summation $q(c+h)+\operatorname{Lap}(3 / \epsilon)$ in this algorithm can be rewritten as an in instance of Laplace mechanism with privacy parameter $\epsilon / 3$ and input $q(c+h)$. Consequently, HSS executes one instance of a histogram mechanism, H, an unbounded number of SVT instances, and an unbounded number of Laplace mechanisms. The Laplace mechanism with privacy parameter $\epsilon / 3$ is a NIM that is known to be $\epsilon / 3$-DP when receiving real values differing by at most 1 . In other words, the Laplace mechanism is a CM that is $\epsilon / 3$-DP w.r.t. a verification function $f_{\text {Lap }}$ that returns $\top$ if and only if it receives a single input message $m=\left(m_{0}, m_{1}\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{2}$ satisfying $\left|m_{0}-m_{1}\right| \leq 1$.

The output of H is a vector in $\mathbb{R}^{d}$, while the output of the Laplace mechanism is a scalar in $\mathbb{R}$. Rounding up each real-valued output to the nearest integer does not affect privacy guarantees (by the post-processing lemma) but increases the additive error of each mechanism by at most 1. This extra error is negligible compared to their original error. Therefore, we assume that both H and the Laplace mechanism have discrete answer distributions. Since the answer set of SVT is finite, it also has discrete answer distributions.

By design, HSS uses the inputs $x^{(t)}$ only to determine the inputs of its sub-mechanisms, and every other action is taken solely based on the privatized outputs of the sub-mechanisms. This allows us to apply Theorem 6.1 to analyze the privacy of HSS based on the privacy parameters of its sub-mechanisms.

By Lemma 7.3, each instance of SVT created by HSS is $\epsilon / 3$-DP. Furthermore, for any two neighboring input streams, fixing the history of privatized outputs of the sub-mechanisms, HSS provides identical inputs to all but one SVT instance, which receives neighboring inputs. By Theorem 5.2, the parallel concurrent composition of all SVT instances is $\epsilon / 3$-DP.

Similarly, HSS gives identical real-valued inputs to all but one instance of the Laplace mechanism, where the differing inputs vary by at most 1 . This implies that the concurrent composition of all Laplace mechanisms is also $\epsilon / 3$-DP. Each concurrent composition is itself a continual mechanism. Additionally, it is given that H is $\epsilon / 3$-DP. By basic composition, the composition of three instances of $\mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon / 3,0}$ is $\epsilon$-DP. Therefore, by Theorem 4.10, the concurrent composition of all mechanisms-H, SVT instances, and Laplace mechanisms - is $\epsilon$-DP. Applying Theorem 6.1, the mechanism HSS is $\epsilon$-DP.

In the case where H is $(\epsilon / 3, \delta)$-DP, since the composition of $\mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon / 3,0}, \mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon / 3,0}$, and $\mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon / 3, \delta}$ is $(\epsilon, \delta)$-DP, the mechanism HSS is also $(\epsilon, \delta)$-DP. Both privacy guarantees provided in this section hold against adaptive adversaries.
