# Appendix A. Overview and Modification of [18] 

In this section, we overview and modify the results of [18]. The original proof relies on the existence of a constant $T$ that upper bounds the number of queries adversaries ask; however, our modified construction does not. Moreover, an algorithmic construction in [18]'s proof needs the answer set to be finite. Using mathematical tools, we formalize their construction and weaken this assumption to having discrete answer distributions. We show:

Lemma A.1. For $\epsilon>0$ and $0 \leq \delta \leq 1$, let $\mathcal{M}: S_{\mathcal{M}} \times Q_{\mathcal{M}} \rightarrow S_{\mathcal{M}} \times A_{\mathcal{M}}$ be an $(\epsilon, \delta)$-DP IM w.r.t. a neighboring relation $\sim$. Suppose that $\mathcal{M}$ has discrete answer distributions. Then, for any two neighboring initial states $s_{0}$ and $s_{1}$, there exists an IPM $\mathcal{P}$ such that for each $b \in\{0,1\}$, the mechanisms $\mathcal{M}\left(s_{b}\right)$ and $\mathcal{P} \circ^{*} \mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon, \delta}(b)$ are identical.

Notation A.2. For short, let $Q=Q_{\mathcal{M}}$ and $A=A_{\mathcal{M}}$. For any $T \in \mathbb{N}$, let $[T]=\{1, \ldots, T\}$. For each $t \in \mathbb{N}$ and $b \in\{0,1\}$, we define the function $\mu_{t}^{b}:(Q \times A)^{t} \rightarrow[0,1]$ such that $\mu_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)$ denotes the probability of $\mathcal{M}\left(s_{b}\right)$ returning answers $a_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}$ to the queries $q_{1}, \ldots, q_{t}$.

Fixing an upper bound $T$ on the number of queries, Lyu [18] reduces the construction of $\mathcal{P}$ to defining a sequence of functions $\phi_{t}^{0}$ and $\phi_{t}^{1}$ for each $t \in[T]$, satisfying three conditions. They then inductively construct each $\phi_{t}^{b}$ and verify that it satisfies the required conditions. The definition of these conditions is based on a sequence of control function $\mathrm{L}_{t, T}^{0}$ and $\mathrm{L}_{t, T}^{1}$, which have backward recursive definitions for $t$ from $T$ to 1 .

In Section A.1.1, we overview the definition of $\mathrm{L}_{t, T}^{b}$ and its properties. In Section A.1.2, we introduce a new control function $\mathrm{L}_{t}^{b}$ with no dependency on $T$. The goal is to use $\mathrm{L}_{t}^{b}$ instead of $\mathrm{L}_{t, T}^{b}$ in [18]'s proofs. So, in Section A.1.3, we show some properties for $\mathrm{L}_{t}^{b}$, required in later proofs.

In Section A.2, we overview the reduction presented in [18], with the control functions $\mathrm{L}_{t, T}^{b}$ replaced by $\mathrm{L}_{t}^{b}$. In this section, we prove the reduction still holds with the new control functions. Finally, in Section A.3, we present a construction for $\phi_{t}$ and show it satisfies all three conditions. We note that this construction is identical in essence to one given in [18], but we extend the proof to work with weaker assumptions.

# A.1. Preliminaries. 

A.1.1. Control Functions $\operatorname{Lower}_{t, T}$ and $\mathrm{L}_{t, T}$. Lyu [18] introduces the following control function:

Definition A. 3 (Lower $_{t, T}$ ). For $T \in \mathbb{N}, b \in\{0,1\}$, and $t \in[T]$, the function $\operatorname{Lower}_{t, T}^{b}:(Q \times A)^{t-1} \times$ $Q \rightarrow[0,1]$ is defined recursively as follows: for each transcript $\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}\right) \in(Q \times A)^{t-1} \times Q$,

$$
\operatorname{Lower}_{t, T}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}\right)= \begin{cases}\sum_{a_{t} \in A} \sup _{q_{t+1} \in Q} \operatorname{Lower}_{t+1, T}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots a_{t}, q_{t+1}\right), & t<T \\ \sum_{a_{t} \in A} \max \left\{0, \mu_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)-e^{\epsilon} \mu_{t}^{1-b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)\right\}, & t=T\end{cases}
$$

We introduce another control function $\mathrm{L}_{t, T}$ based on Lower $_{t, T}$ :
Definition A. $4\left(\mathrm{~L}_{t, T}^{b}\right)$. For $T \in \mathbb{N}, b \in\{0,1\}$, and $t \in[T]$, the function $\mathrm{L}_{t, T}^{b}:(Q \times A)^{t} \rightarrow[0,1]$ is defined recursively as follows: for each transcript $\left(q_{1}, \ldots a_{t}\right) \in(Q \times A)^{t}$,

$$
\mathrm{L}_{t, T}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)= \begin{cases}\sup _{q_{t+1} \in Q} \operatorname{Lower}_{t+1, T}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}, q_{t+1}\right), & t<T \\ \max \left\{0, \mu_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)-e^{\epsilon} \mu_{t}^{1-b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)\right\}, & t=T\end{cases}
$$

The following corollary follows directly from the definitions of $\operatorname{Lower}_{t, T}^{b}$ and $\mathrm{L}_{t, T}^{b}$ :
Corollary A.5. For every $T \in \mathbb{N}, b \in\{0,1\}, t \in[T]$, and $\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}\right) \in(Q \times A)^{t-1} \times Q$,

$$
\operatorname{Lower}_{t, T}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}\right)=\sum_{a_{t} \in A} \mathrm{~L}_{t, T}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)
$$

Lyu [18] shows the following two claims about Lower $_{t, T}^{b}$ :
Claim A.6 ([18]). For each $b \in\{0,1\}, T \in \mathbb{N}$, and $q_{1} \in Q \operatorname{Lower}_{1, T}^{b}\left(q_{1}\right) \leq \delta$.
Claim A. 7 ([18]). For each $b \in\{0,1\}, T \in \mathbb{N}, t \in[T]^{3}$, and transcript $\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}\right) \in$ $(Q \times A)^{t-1} \times Q$, we have
$\operatorname{Lower}_{t, T}^{b}\left(q_{1}, a_{1}, \ldots, q_{t}\right)-e^{-\epsilon} \operatorname{Lower}_{t, T}^{1-b}\left(q_{1}, a_{1}, \ldots, q_{t}\right) \leq \mu_{t-1}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}\right)-e^{-\epsilon} \mu_{t-1}^{1-b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}\right)$.
Claim A. 6 combined with the definition of $\mathrm{L}_{t, T}^{b}$ imply:
Corollary A.8. For each $b \in\{0,1\}$, and $T \in \mathbb{N}, \mathrm{~L}_{0, T}^{b}() \leq \delta$.
As we point out later, in some part of the proof, Lyu [18] wrongly refers to Claim A.7, while the following lemma is required. For completeness, we prove this lemma and use it in the next section.
Lemma A.9. For each $b \in\{0,1\}, T \in \mathbb{N}, t \in[T] \cup\{0\}$, and transcript $\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right) \in(Q \times A)^{t}$, we have

$$
\mathrm{L}_{t, T}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)-e^{-\epsilon} \mathrm{L}_{t, T}^{1-b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right) \leq \mu_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)-e^{-\epsilon} \mu_{t}^{1-b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)
$$

Proof. For $t=T$, we need to show that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \max \left\{0, \mu_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)-e^{\epsilon} \mu_{t}^{1-b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)\right\}-e^{-\epsilon} \max \left\{0, \mu_{t}^{1-b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)-e^{\epsilon} \mu_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)\right\} \\
& \leq \mu_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)-e^{-\epsilon} \mu_{t}^{1-b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

For short, we refer to the LHS and RHS as $A$ and $B$, respectively. There are three cases:

- If $\mu_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right) \leq e^{\epsilon} \mu_{t}^{1-b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)$, then $A=\mu_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)-e^{-\epsilon} \mu_{t}^{1-b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)$, which is at most $B$.
- If $\mu_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right) \geq e^{-\epsilon} \mu_{t}^{1-b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)$, then, $A=\mu_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)-e^{\epsilon} \mu_{t}^{1-b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)$, which is at most $B$ as $e^{\epsilon} \geq e^{-\epsilon}$.

- Otherwise, if $e^{-\epsilon} \mu_{t}^{1-b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)<\mu_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)<e^{\epsilon} \mu_{t}^{1-b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right), A=0$ is at most $B$ since by the condition of the case distinction, $B=\mu_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)-e^{-\epsilon} \mu_{t}^{1-b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)$ is positive.
For $t<T$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathrm{L}_{t, T}^{b}\left(q_{1}, a_{1}, \ldots, q_{t}\right)-e^{-\epsilon} \mathrm{L}_{t, T}^{1-b}\left(q_{1}, a_{1}, \ldots, q_{t}\right) \\
& =\sup _{q_{t+1} \in Q} \operatorname{Lower}_{t+1, T}^{b}\left(q_{1}, a_{1}, \ldots, q_{t+1}\right)-e^{-\epsilon} \sup _{q_{t+1} \in Q} \operatorname{Lower}_{t+1, T}^{1-b}\left(q_{1}, a_{1}, \ldots, q_{t+1}\right) \\
& \leq \sup _{q_{t+1} \in Q}\left(\operatorname{Lower}_{t, T}^{b}\left(q_{1}, a_{1}, \ldots, q_{t+1}\right)-e^{-\epsilon} \operatorname{Lower}_{t, T}^{1-b}\left(q_{1}, a_{1}, \ldots, q_{t+1}\right)\right) \\
& \leq \mu_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)-e^{-\epsilon} \mu_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where the last inequality holds because for every $q_{t+1} \in Q$, by Claim A. 7

$$
\operatorname{Lower}_{t+1, T}^{b}\left(q_{1}, a_{1}, \ldots, q_{t+1}\right)-e^{-\epsilon} \operatorname{Lower}_{t+1, T}^{1-b}\left(q_{1}, a_{1}, \ldots, q_{t+1}\right) \leq \mu_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)-e^{-\epsilon} \mu_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)
$$

A.1.2. Control Function $\mathrm{L}_{t}^{b}$ with is the Limit of $\mathrm{L}_{t, T}$ (Definition). This section introduces our main new technical contribution. We introduce $\mathrm{L}_{t}^{b}$ as limit of $\mathrm{L}_{t, T}^{b}$ and show that it satisfies all properties needed by the proof of [18]. Thus, differently from [18], we will use $\mathrm{L}_{t}^{b}$ to define the functions $\phi_{t}^{0}$ and $\phi_{t}^{1}$.

However, we first need to argue that the limit of $\mathrm{L}_{t, T}^{b}$ exists. the value of $\mathrm{L}_{t, T}^{b}$ is upper bounded by 1 . We also show that this function is non-decreasing in $T$. As a result, for each each $t \in \mathbb{N} \cup\{0\}$ and $\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right) \in(Q \times A)^{t}$, the limit $\lim _{T \geq t, T \rightarrow \infty} \mathrm{~L}_{t, T}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)$ exists. To remove the assumption of having an upper bound $T$ on the number of queries, we introduce the following control function:
Definition A. $10\left(\mathrm{~L}_{t}^{b}\right)$. For each $b \in\{0,1\}$ and $t \in \mathbb{N}$, the function $\mathrm{L}_{t}^{b}:(Q \times A)^{t} \rightarrow[0,1]$ is defined as follows: for each transcript $\left(q_{1}, \ldots a_{t}\right) \in(Q \times A)^{t}$,

$$
\mathrm{L}_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}\right)=\lim _{T \geq t, T \rightarrow \infty} \mathrm{~L}_{t, T}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}\right)
$$

We need the following lemma throughout the section:
Lemma A.11. For every $t \in \mathbb{N}$, transcript $\left(q_{1}, \ldots a_{t-1}\right) \in(Q \times A)^{t-1}$, and query $q_{t} \in Q$, we have

$$
\mu_{t-1}^{b}\left(q_{1}, a_{1}, \ldots, q_{t-1}, a_{t-1}\right)=\sum_{a_{t} \in A} \mu_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, a_{1}, \ldots, q_{t}, a_{t}\right)
$$

Proof. For $a_{t} \in A$, let $\mu_{t}^{b}\left(a_{t} \mid q_{1}, a_{1}, \ldots, q_{t-1}, a_{t-1}, q_{t}\right)$ denote the probability that $\mathcal{M}\left(s_{b}\right)$ returns the answer $a_{t}$ in response to $q_{t}$ conditioned on $q_{1}, a_{1}, \ldots, q_{t-1}, a_{t-1}$ being the history of previous queries and answers. By the chain rule, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mu_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, a_{1}, \ldots, q_{t}, a_{t}\right) & =\sum_{a_{t} \in A} \mu_{t-1}^{b}\left(q_{1}, a_{1}, \ldots, q_{t-1}, a_{t-1}\right) \cdot \mu_{t}^{b}\left(a_{t} \mid q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}\right) \\
& =\mu_{t-1}^{b}\left(q_{1}, a_{1}, \ldots, q_{t-1}, a_{t-1}\right) \sum_{a_{t} \in A} \mu_{t}^{b}\left(a_{t} \mid q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}\right) \\
& =\mu_{t-1}^{b}\left(q_{1}, a_{1}, \ldots, q_{t-1}, a_{t-1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

To upper bound $\mathrm{L}_{t, T}$, we first need to upper bound Lower ${ }_{t, T}$ :
Lemma A.12. For every $T \in \mathbb{N}, b \in\{0,1\}, t \in[T]$, and transcript $\left(q_{1}, \ldots a_{t-1}, q_{t}\right) \in(Q \times A)^{t-1} \times Q$,

$$
\operatorname{Lower}_{t, T}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots a_{t-1}, q_{t}\right) \leq \mu_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}\right)
$$

Proof. Fix $T \geq t$. The proof is by induction on $t$ from $T$ to 1 . For $t=T$, by definition and Lemma A.11, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{Lower}_{t, T}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots a_{t-1}, q_{t}\right) & =\sum_{a_{t} \in A} \max \left\{0, \mu_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)-e^{\epsilon} \mu_{t}^{1-b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)\right\} \\
& \leq \sum_{a_{t} \in A} \max \left\{0, \mu_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)\right\}=\mu_{t-1}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

For $t<T$, by the inductive hypothesis,

$$
\operatorname{Lower}_{t, T}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}\right) \leq \sum_{a_{t} \in A} \sup _{q_{t+1} \in Q} \mu_{t-1}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots a_{t}\right)=\sum_{a_{t} \in A} \mu_{t-1}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots a_{t}\right)=\mu_{t-1}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}\right)
$$

completing the induction.
The following lemma implies that the values of $\mathrm{L}_{t, T}$ are upper bounded by 1 .
Lemma A.13. For every $T \in \mathbb{N}, b \in\{0,1\}, t \in[T] \cup\{0\}$, and transcript $\left(q_{1}, \ldots a_{t}\right) \in(Q \times A)^{t}$,

$$
\mathrm{L}_{t, T}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots a_{t}\right) \leq \mu_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)
$$

Proof. For $t=T$, by definition and Lemma A.11, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{L}_{t, T}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right) & =\max \left\{0, \mu_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)-e^{\epsilon} \mu_{t}^{1-b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)\right\} \\
& \leq \max \left\{0, \mu_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)\right\}=\mu_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

For $t<T$, by Lemma A. 12,

$$
\mathrm{L}_{t, T}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)=\sup _{q_{t+1} \in Q} \operatorname{Lower}_{t+1, T}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}, q_{t+1}\right) \leq \sup _{q_{t} \in Q} \mu_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)=\mu_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)
$$

To ensure the function $\mathrm{L}_{t}^{b}$ is well-defined, it remains to show that $\mathrm{L}_{t, T}^{b}$ is non-decreasing in $T$. To prove so, we first need to show:
Lemma A.14. For each $b \in\{0,1\}$ and $t \in \mathbb{N}$, the function $\operatorname{Lower}_{t, T}^{b}$ is monotonically non-decreasing in $T$.

Proof. We need to show that for every $T \in \mathbb{N}, b \in\{0,1\}, t \leq T$, and transcript $\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}\right) \in$ $(Q \times A)^{t-1} \times Q$

$$
\operatorname{Lower}_{t, T}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}\right) \leq \operatorname{Lower}_{t, T+1}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}\right)
$$

Fix $T \in \mathbb{N}$ and $b \in\{0,1\}$. We show this by reverse induction on $t$.
The base case is $t=T$. By Lemma A.11, for every $\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}\right)$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \operatorname{Lower}_{T, T}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{T-1}, q_{T}\right)=\sum_{a_{T} \in A} \max \left\{0, \mu_{T}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{T}\right)-e^{\epsilon} \mu_{T}^{1-b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{T}\right)\right\} \\
& =\sum_{a_{T} \in A} \sup _{q_{T+1} \in Q} \max \left\{0, \sum_{a_{T+1} \in A} \mu_{T+1}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{T+1}\right)-e^{\epsilon} \mu_{T+1}^{1-b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{T+1}\right)\right\} \\
& \leq \sum_{a_{T} \in A} \sup _{q_{T+1} \in Q} \sum_{a_{T+1} \in A} \max \left\{0, \mu_{T+1}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{T+1}\right)-e^{\epsilon} \mu_{T+1}^{1-b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{T+1}\right)\right\} \\
& =\sum_{a_{T} \in A} \sup _{q_{T+1} \in Q} \operatorname{Lower}_{T+1, T+1}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{T}, q_{T+1}\right) \\
& =\operatorname{Lower}_{T, T+1}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{T-1}, q_{T}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

For the induction step, assume that $t<T$ and that for every $\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}, q_{t+1}\right)$, we have $\operatorname{Lower}_{t+1, T}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}, q_{t+1}\right) \leq \operatorname{Lower}_{t+1, T+1}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}, q_{t+1}\right)$. We need to show $\operatorname{Lower}_{t, T}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}\right) \leq \operatorname{Lower}_{t, T+1}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}\right)$ for every $\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}\right)$. By definition,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{Lower}_{t, T}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}\right) & =\sum_{a_{t} \in A} \sup _{q_{t+1} \in Q} \operatorname{Lower}_{t+1, T}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots a_{t}, q_{t+1}\right) \\
& \leq \sum_{a_{t} \in A} \sup _{q_{t+1} \in Q} \operatorname{Lower}_{t+1, T+1}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots a_{t}, q_{t+1}\right) \\
& =\operatorname{Lower}_{t, T+1}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Lemma A.15. For each $b \in\{0,1\}$ and $t \in \mathbb{N} \cup\{0\}$, the function $\mathrm{L}_{t, T}^{b}$ is monotonically non-decreasing in $T$.

Proof. We need to show that for every $T \in \mathbb{N}, t \in[T] \cup\{0\}$, and transcript $\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right) \in(Q \times A)^{t}$,

$$
\mathrm{L}_{t, T}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right) \leq \mathrm{L}_{t, T+1}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)
$$

Fix $T \in \mathbb{N}$ and $b \in\{0,1\}$. We show this by reverse induction on $t$ from $T$ to 0 .
The base case is $t=T$. By Lemma A.11, for every $\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{T}\right)$ we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathrm{L}_{T, T}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{T}\right)=\max \left\{0, \mu_{T}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{T}\right)-e^{\epsilon} \mu_{T}^{1-b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{T}\right)\right\} \\
& =\sup _{q_{T+1} \in Q} \max \left\{0, \sum_{a_{T+1} \in A} \mu_{T+1}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{T+1}\right)-e^{\epsilon} \mu_{T+1}^{1-b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{T+1}\right)\right)\right\} \\
& \leq \sup _{q_{T+1} \in Q} \sum_{a_{T+1} \in A} \max \left\{0, \mu_{T+1}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{T+1}\right)-e^{\epsilon} \mu_{T+1}^{1-b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{T+1}\right)\right\} \\
& =\sup _{q_{T+1} \in Q} \operatorname{Lower}_{T+1, T+1}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{T}, q_{T+1}\right) \\
& =\mathrm{L}_{T, T+1}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{T-1}, q_{T}, a_{T}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

For the induction step, assume that $t<T$ and that for every $\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t+1}\right)$, we have $\mathrm{L}_{t+1, T}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t+1}\right) \leq \mathrm{L}_{t+1, T+1}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t+1}\right)$. We need to show $\mathrm{L}_{t, T}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right) \leq \mathrm{L}_{t, T+1}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)$ for every $\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)$. By definition of $\mathrm{L}_{t, T+1}$ and Lemma A.14, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{L}_{t, T}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, q_{t}, a_{t}\right) & =\sup _{q_{t+1} \in Q} \operatorname{Lower}_{t+1, T}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots a_{t}, q_{t+1}\right) \\
& \leq \sup _{q_{t+1} \in Q} \operatorname{Lower}_{t+1, T+1}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots a_{t}, q_{t+1}\right) \\
& =\mathrm{L}_{t, T+1}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, q_{t}, a_{t}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

A.1.3. Control Function $\mathrm{L}_{t}^{b}$ (Properties). In this section, we present the properties of $\mathrm{L}_{t}^{b}$, required in the next sections.

The definition of $\mathrm{L}_{t}^{b}$ combined with Corollary A.8, Lemma A.9, and Lemma A. 13 give the following corollaries, respectively:
Corollary A.16. For each $b \in\{0,1\}, \mathrm{L}_{0}^{b}() \leq \delta$.
Corollary A.17. For each $b \in\{0,1\}, t \in \mathbb{N} \cup\{0\}$, and transcript $\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right) \in(Q \times A)^{t}$, we have

$$
\mathrm{L}_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)-e^{-\epsilon} \mathrm{L}_{t}^{1-b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right) \leq \mu_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)-e^{-\epsilon} \mu_{t}^{1-b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)
$$

Lemma A.18. For each $b \in\{0,1\}, t \in \mathbb{N}$, and transcript $\left(q_{1}, \ldots a_{t}\right) \in(Q \times A)^{t}$,

$$
\mathrm{L}_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots a_{t}\right) \leq \mu_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)
$$

To show the next property, we need the following known fact:
Lemma A. 19 (Monotone Convergence). Let $f: \mathbb{N}^{2} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ be a function such that $\sum_{m} f(m, 1)>-\infty$ and that is non-decreasing in the second parameter. Then

$$
\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \sum_{m=1}^{\infty} f(m, n)=\sum_{m=1}^{\infty} \lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} f(m, n)
$$

Lemma A. 19 combined with Lemma A. 15 implies:
Corollary A.20. For any $b \in\{0,1\}, t \in \mathbb{N}$, and $\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}\right) \in(Q \times A)^{t-1} \times Q$,

$$
\sum_{a_{t} \in A} \lim _{T \geq t, T \rightarrow \infty} \mathrm{~L}_{t, T}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)=\lim _{T \geq t, T \rightarrow \infty} \sum_{a_{t} \in A} \mathrm{~L}_{t, T}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)
$$

Lemma A.21. For every $b \in\{0,1\}, t \in \mathbb{N}$, transcript $\left(q_{1}, \ldots a_{t-1}\right) \in(Q \times A)^{t-1}$, and query $q_{t} \in Q$,

$$
\mathrm{L}_{t-1}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots a_{t-1}\right) \geq \sum_{a_{t} \in A} \mathrm{~L}_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots a_{t}\right)
$$

Proof. First, we will show that for any $T>t-1$,

$$
\mathrm{L}_{t-1, T}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots a_{t-1}\right) \geq \sum_{a_{t} \in A} \mathrm{~L}_{t, T}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots a_{t}\right)
$$

Since $t \neq T$, by definition of $\mathrm{L}_{t-1, T}^{b}$ and Corollary A.5, we have

$$
\mathrm{L}_{t-1, T}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots a_{t-1}\right)=\sup _{q \in Q} \operatorname{Lower}_{t, T}\left(q_{1}, \ldots a_{t-1}, q\right) \geq \operatorname{Lower}_{t, T}\left(q_{1}, \ldots a_{t-1}, q_{t}\right)=\sum_{a_{t} \in A} \mathrm{~L}_{t, T}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots a_{t}\right)
$$

Thus, by Corollary A.20, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{L}_{t-1}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots a_{t-1}\right) & =\lim _{T \geq t-1, T \rightarrow \infty} \mathrm{~L}_{t-1, T}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots a_{t-1}\right)=\lim _{T \geq t, T \rightarrow \infty} \mathrm{~L}_{t-1, T}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots a_{t-1}\right) \\
& \geq \lim _{T \geq t, T \rightarrow \infty} \sum_{a_{t} \in A} \mathrm{~L}_{t, T}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots a_{t}\right)=\sum_{a_{t} \in A} \lim _{T \geq t, T \rightarrow \infty} \mathrm{~L}_{t, T}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots a_{t}\right)=\sum_{a_{t} \in A} \mathrm{~L}_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots a_{t}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

A.2. Reduction. To define $\mathcal{P}$, Lyu [18] constructs four families of PMFs $\mathcal{F}_{(0, \perp)}, \mathcal{F}_{(1, \perp)}, \mathcal{F}_{(0, \top)}$, and $\mathcal{F}_{(1, \top)}$, corresponding to each outcome of $\mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon, \delta}$. Intuitively, each family describes an IM. Specifically, each family consists of PMFs over the answer set $A$ for every $t \in[T]$ and every history $\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}\right) \in(Q \times A)^{t} \times Q$, representing the probability of returning each answer in response to $q_{t}$, conditioned on $q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}$ being the history of queries and answers.
A.2.1. Constructing $\mathcal{P}$ using $\mathcal{F}_{r} s$. Roughly speaking, in the interaction between $\mathcal{P} \circ^{*} \mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon, \delta}(b)$ and an adversary $\mathcal{A}, \mathcal{P}$ interacts with $\mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon, \delta}(b)$ once and stores its output $r$ as thee first parameter in its state. It then answers the adversary's queries by itself using the PMFs provided by $\mathcal{F}_{r}$. Specifically, $\mathcal{P}$ has a single initial state (null, ()), where null is an empty field and () represents an empty sequence. Let $h$ denote the sequence of interactions between $\mathcal{P}$ and $\mathcal{A}$, which is stored by $\mathcal{P}$ as second parameter of its state. After interacting with $\mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon, \delta}(b), \mathcal{P}$ updates null to $r$. Moreover, upon receiving a query $q$ and before returning an answer $a, \mathcal{P}$ appends $q$ and $a$ to the history sequence $h$. To generate a response $a$ to a query $q, \mathcal{P}$ samples $a$ from the PMF corresponding to $(h, q)$ in $\mathcal{F}_{r}$, where $h$ is the history of all previous queries and answers.

A.2.2. Constructing $\mathcal{F}_{\left(b, \perp\right)} s$. Lyu [18] constructs a function $\phi_{t}:(Q \times A)^{t} \rightarrow[0,1]^{2}$ for each $t \in$ $[T] \cup\{0\}$. Let $\phi_{t}^{0}$ and $\phi_{t}^{1}$ denote the functions returning the first and second elements of the output pairs of $\phi_{t}$. For each $b \in\{0,1\}$, the family $\mathcal{F}_{\left(b, \perp\right)}$ is defined based on $\phi_{t}^{b} \mathrm{~s}$. Intuitively, $\phi_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)$ represents the probability that $\mathcal{M}\left(s_{b}\right)$ returns the answers $a_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}$ to the fixed queries $q_{1}, \ldots, q_{t}$. That is, for each query sequence $q_{1}, \ldots, q_{t}, \phi_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \cdot, q_{2}, \cdot, \ldots, q_{t}, \cdot\right)$ is a PMF over $A^{t}$.

We do not provide the construction of $\phi_{t}$ in this section. However, assuming the existence of $\phi_{t}$ satisfying the following three conditions, we show that for every $b \in\{0,1\}$, the mechanisms $\mathcal{P} \circ^{*} \mathrm{RR}_{e, \delta}$ and $\mathcal{M}\left(s_{b}\right)$ are equivalent. These three conditions were originally stated in [18], with the control function $\mathrm{L}_{t, T}^{b}$ instead of $\mathrm{L}_{t}^{b}$.

For $t=0$, let $\phi_{t}()=(1,1)$. Suppose for every $t \in[T]$, there exists a function $\phi_{t}:(Q \times A)^{t} \rightarrow[0,1]^{2}$ satisfying the following conditions for each $b \in\{0,1\}$ :
(I) For any transcript $\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right) \in(Q \times A)^{t}$,

$$
\delta \phi_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right) \geq \mathrm{L}_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)
$$

(II) For any transcript $\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right) \in(Q \times A)^{t}$,

$$
\delta \phi_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)-e^{-\epsilon} \delta \phi_{t}^{1-b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right) \leq \mu_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)-e^{-\epsilon} \mu_{t}^{1-b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)
$$

(III) For any transcript $\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}\right) \in(Q \times A)^{t-1} \times Q$,

$$
\sum_{a \in A} \phi_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}, a\right)=\phi_{t-1}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}\right)
$$

For each $b \in\{0,1\}$, the family $\mathcal{F}_{\left(b, \perp\right)}$ consists of functions $f_{q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}}^{b}: A \rightarrow[0,1]$ for each $\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}\right) \in \bigcup_{t=1}^{T}(Q \times A)^{t-1} \times Q$, where $f_{q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}}^{b}$ is defined as follows:

- If $\phi_{t-1}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}\right)>0$, then for each answer $a_{t} \in A$,

$$
f_{q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}}^{b}\left(a_{t}\right)=\frac{\phi_{t}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)}{\phi_{t-1}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}\right)}
$$

- Otherwise, if $\phi_{t-1}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}\right)=0, f_{q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}}^{b}\left(a_{t}\right)=0$ for every answer, except for one fixed arbitrary answer $a^{*} \in A$, where $f_{q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}}^{b}\left(a^{*}\right)=1$. This case is included only for formality, and the corresponding PMFs are never used by $\mathcal{P}$.
Since $\phi_{t-1}$ and $\phi_{t}$ are non-negative, $f_{q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}}^{b}\left(a_{t}\right)$ is also non-negative. Furthermore, by (III), we have $\sum_{a_{t} \in A} f_{q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}}^{b}(a)=1$, implying that $f_{q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}}^{b}\left(a_{t}\right)$ is a PMF.
A.2.3. Constructing $\mathcal{F}_{\left(b, \top\right)} s$. Similar to the previous section, $\mathcal{F}_{\left(0, \top\right)}$ and $\mathcal{F}_{\left(1, \top\right)}$ are defined based on a sequence of functions $\psi_{t}:(Q \times A)^{t} \rightarrow[0,1]^{2}$ for each $t \in[T] \cup\{0\}$. For $t=0, \psi_{t}()=(1,1)$. For $t \in[T], \psi_{t}$ is defined as follows:
- If $\delta=1$, then $\psi_{t}$ is identical to $\phi_{t}$.
- Otherwise, for each $b \in\{0,1\}$ and $\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right) \in(Q \times A)^{t}, \psi_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)$ equals

$$
\frac{1}{(1-\delta)\left(e^{\epsilon}-1\right)}\left(e^{\epsilon} \mu_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)-\delta e^{\epsilon} \phi_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)-\mu_{t}^{1-b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)+\delta \phi_{t}^{1-b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)\right)
$$

For each $b \in\{0,1\}$, the family $\mathcal{F}_{\left(b, \top\right)}$ consists of functions $g_{q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}}^{b}: A \rightarrow[0,1]$ for each $\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}\right) \in \bigcup_{t=1}^{T}(Q \times A)^{t-1} \times Q$, where $g_{q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}}^{b}$ is defined as follows:

- If $\psi_{t-1}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}\right)>0$, then for each answer $a_{t} \in A$,

$$
g_{q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}}^{b}\left(a_{t}\right)=\frac{\psi_{t}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)}{\psi_{t-1}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}\right)}
$$

- Otherwise, $g_{q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}}^{b}\left(a_{t}\right)=0$ for every answer, except for one fixed arbitrary answer $a^{*} \in A$, where $g_{q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}}^{b}\left(a^{*}\right)=1$.

By condition (II), each $\psi_{t}^{b}$ is non-negative. Also, by Lemma A. 11 and condition (III), for every $\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}, q_{t}\right) \in(Q \times A)^{t-1} \times Q$

$$
\sum_{a \in A} \psi_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}, a\right)=\psi_{t-1}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}\right)
$$

implying that each $g_{q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}}^{b}$ forms a valid PMF.
A.2.4. Proof of Lemma A.1. By definition of RR and of $\mathcal{P}$, for each $t \in \mathbb{N}$ and transcript $\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right) \in$ $(Q \times A)^{t}$, the probability of $\mathcal{P} \circ^{*} \mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon, \delta}(b)$ returning the answers $a_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}$ to the queries $q_{1}, \ldots, q_{t}$ is

$$
\delta \phi_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)+(1-\delta) \frac{e^{\epsilon}}{1+e^{\epsilon}} \psi_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)+(1-\delta) \frac{1}{1+e^{\epsilon}} \psi_{t}^{1-b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)
$$

by the definition of $\psi_{t}$, this probability equals

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \delta \phi_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)+\frac{e^{\epsilon}}{\left(1+e^{\epsilon}\right)\left(e^{\epsilon}-1\right)}\left(e^{\epsilon} \mu_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)\right. \\
& \quad-\delta e^{\epsilon} \phi_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)-\mu_{t}^{1-b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)+\delta \phi_{t}^{1-b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)\right) \\
& \quad+\frac{1}{\left(1+e^{\epsilon}\right)\left(e^{\epsilon}-1\right)}\left(e^{\epsilon} \mu_{t}^{1-b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)-\delta e^{\epsilon} \phi_{t}^{1-b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)-\mu_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)+\delta \phi_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)\right) \\
& =\mu_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, the views of any adversary interacting with $\mathcal{M}\left(s_{b}\right)$ and $\mathcal{P} \circ^{*} \mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon, \delta}(b)$ are identically distributed, implying that these mechanisms are equivalent.
A.3. Construction of $\phi_{t}$. In this section, we formalize the construction of [18] differently to remove the finiteness assumption on $A$.

Roughly speaking, Lyu [18] initializes the values of $\phi_{t}$ with the ones from $\mathrm{L}_{t}$. Then, for each $q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}$, they iterate over all possible answers $a_{t} \in A$ in a fixed order and gradually increase the value of $\phi_{t}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)$ to satisfy conditions (II) and (III), while ensuring that condition (I) remains valid. This iterative procedure requires $A$ to be finite; otherwise, the construction algorithm does not terminate. To extend this approach to infinite $A$, we define $\phi_{t}$ mathematically and apply the transfinite recursion theorem to prove its existence.

For each $t \in \mathbb{N}$, knowing that $\phi_{t-1}$ exists and satisfies condition (I), we construct $\phi_{t}$ and show it satisfies conditions (I), (II), and (III). For $t=0$, we set $\phi_{0}()=(1,1)$. By Corollary A.16, $\phi_{0}$ satisfies condition (I).

Remark A.22. In the rest of this section, we assume $\phi_{t-1}$ exists and satisfies condition (I).
In Section A.3.1, we introduce the necessary preliminaries for formally defining $\phi_{t}$ when $A$ is infinite. In Section A.3.2, we construct $\phi_{t}$, and in Section A.3.3, we prove that $\phi_{t}$ satisfies conditions (I) to (III).
A.3.1. Preliminaries. In this section, we introduce the fundamental concepts and notations needed for defining $\phi_{t}$ when $A$ is not finite.
Definition A. 23 (Well-Order). A well-order on a set $X$ is a total order (i.e., for every $x, y \in X$, either $x<y, x>y$, or $x=y$ ) such that every non-empty subset of $X$ has a least element.

Since $A$ is countable, we can inject $A$ into $\mathbb{N}$. By listing elements of $A$ in the order given by their images under this injection, we get a well-order $<_{A}$ on $A$. Note that for any non-empty subset $B \subseteq A$, the image of $B$ in $\mathbb{N}$ has a least element, whose preimage is the least element of $B$ under $<_{A}$. We will later use the following remark when constructing $\xi_{t}$ and $\phi_{t}$.
Remark A.24. By the definition of $<_{A}$, each element of $A$ is either the least element of $A$ or has an immediate predecessor in $A$.

The query set $Q$ is not necessarily countable. However, by the well-ordering theorem (which is equivalent to the axiom of choice), there exists a well-order $<_{Q}$ on $Q$, regardless of its cardinality.
Definition A. 25 (Lexicographic Order $<_{t}$ on $(Q \times A)^{t}$ ). For $t \in \mathbb{N} \cup\{0\}$, we define an order $<_{t}$ on $(Q \times A)^{t}$ by lexicographic comparison: For any two distinct tuples $\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)$ and $\left(q_{1}^{\prime}, \ldots, a_{t}^{\prime}\right)$ in $(Q \times A)^{t}$, let $i$ be the smallest index such that $\left(q_{i}, a_{i}\right) \neq\left(q_{i}^{\prime}, a_{i}^{\prime}\right)$. Then:

$$
\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)<_{t}\left(q_{1}^{\prime}, \ldots, a_{t}^{\prime}\right) \text { if and only if }\left[q_{i}<_{Q} q_{i}^{\prime}\right] \text { or }\left[q_{i}=q_{i}^{\prime} \text { and } a_{i}<_{A} a_{i}^{\prime}\right]
$$

Since $<_{A}$ and $<_{Q}$ are well-orders, $<_{t}$ is also a well-order: $<_{t}$ is clearly a total order. We will show that every non-empty subset $B \subseteq(Q \times A)^{t}$ has a least element. Define

$$
\begin{aligned}
& B_{1}^{Q}=\left\{q \in Q \mid \exists a_{1}, \ldots, a_{t} \in A, \exists q_{2}, \ldots, q_{t} \in Q \text { such that }\left(q, a_{1}, q_{2}, \ldots, a_{t}\right) \in B\right\} \text { and } \\
& B_{1}^{A}=\left\{a \in A \mid \exists a_{2}, \ldots, a_{t} \in A, \exists q_{2}, \ldots, q_{t} \in Q \text { such that }\left(q_{1}^{*}, a, q_{2}, \ldots, a_{t}\right) \in B\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

Since $B$ is non-empty, $B_{1}^{Q}$ is also non-empty. By the well-ordering of $Q, B_{1}^{Q}$ has a least element $q_{1}^{*}$. Similarly, since $B_{1}^{A}$ is non-empty, it has a least element $a_{1}^{*}$.

Again, since $B_{2}^{Q}$ is non-empty, it has a least element $q_{2}^{*}$. Repeating this process $t$ times, we obtain the least element $\left(q_{1}^{*}, \ldots, a_{t}^{*}\right)$ of $B$.
Lemma A. 26 (Transfinite Recursion). Let $f$ be a function recursively defined over $(Q \times A)^{t}$ according to the well-order $<_{t}$. If for each sequence $\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right) \in(Q \times A)^{t}$, the value of $f\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)$ is uniquely determined by the values $f\left(q_{1}^{\prime}, \ldots, a_{t}^{\prime}\right)$ for every $\left(q_{1}^{\prime}, \ldots, a_{t}^{\prime}\right)<_{t}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)$, then $f$ exists and is unique.

In later sections, we define functions $f$ recursively over $(Q \times A)^{t}$ using the well-order $<_{t}$. Specifically, we determine $f\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)$ based on the values $f\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}, a\right)$ for every $a<_{A} a_{t}$. By the definition of $<_{t}$, we have:

$$
\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}, a\right)<_{t}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)
$$

Finally, we define two key sets that will be used in our constructions: for any $a_{t} \in A$,

$$
\Gamma_{<a_{t}}=\left\{a \in A \mid a<_{A} a_{t}\right\}
$$

and

$$
\Gamma_{>a_{t}}=\left\{a \in A \mid a_{t}<_{A} a\right\}
$$

A.3.2. Defining $\phi_{t}$ and showing its existence. We define the function $\phi_{t}:(Q \times A)^{t} \rightarrow[0,1]^{2}$ recursively for each $\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)$ based on the $<_{t}$ order. For each $\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)$, we determine $\phi_{t}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)$ by solving an optimization problem with the variables $\phi_{t}^{0}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)$ and $\phi_{t}^{1}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)$. The constraints for this problem involve the known functions $\mu_{t}, \phi_{t-1}, \mathrm{~L}_{t}$, and the known values $\phi_{t}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}, a\right)$ for every $a \in \Gamma_{<a_{t}}$.

We define $\phi_{t}^{0}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)$ and $\phi_{t}^{1}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)$ as the largest possible real numbers in $[0,1]$ satisfying the following constraints:
$(\phi .1)$ For each $b \in\{0,1\}$,

$$
\delta \phi_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right) \geq \mathrm{L}_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)
$$

$(\phi .2)$ For each $b \in\{0,1\}$,

$$
\sum_{a \in \Gamma_{<a_{t}}} \phi_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}, a\right)+\phi_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)+\sum_{a \in \Gamma_{>a_{t}}} \frac{1}{\delta} \mathrm{~L}_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}, a\right) \leq \phi_{t-1}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}\right)
$$

$(\phi .3)$ For each $b \in\{0,1\}$,

$$
\delta \phi_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)-e^{-\epsilon} \delta \phi_{t}^{1-b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right) \leq \mu_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)-e^{-\epsilon} \mu_{t}^{1-b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)
$$

Although $\Gamma_{<a_{t}}$ is always finite, $\Gamma_{>a_{t}}$ could be infinite. Thus, to ensure ( $\phi .2$ ) is well-defined, we need to show:

Claim A.27. For any $t \in[T], b \in\{0,1\}$, and $\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}\right) \in(Q \times A)^{t-1} \times Q$, the summation $\sum_{a \in \Gamma_{>a_{t}}} \mathrm{~L}_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}, a\right)$ exists.

Proof. By Lemma A.18,

$$
\sum_{a \in \Gamma_{>a_{t}}} \mathrm{~L}_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}, a\right) \leq \sum_{a \in A} \mu_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}, a\right)=\mu_{t-1}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}\right) \leq 1
$$

Moreover each summand $\mathrm{L}_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}, a\right)$ is non-negative, implying that the summation is within the range $[0,1]$, and thus it exists.

Claim A.28. The function $\phi_{t}$ is well-defined and exists.
Proof. The proof consists of two steps: (i) ensuring that the optimization problems are feasible, and (ii) applying the transfinite recursion theorem (Lemma A.26) and proving that $\phi_{t}$ exists.

Fix any $\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}\right) \in(Q \times A)^{t-1} \times Q$. By Remark A.24, each answer in $A$ is either the smallest element of $A$ or has an immediate predecessor. We will inductively show that for every $a_{t} \in A$, the values $\frac{1}{\delta} \mathrm{~L}_{t}^{0}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)$ and $\frac{1}{\delta} \mathrm{~L}_{t}^{1}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)$ satisfy the constraints of the optimization problem defining $\phi_{t}^{0}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)$ and $\phi_{t}^{1}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)$.
$\frac{1}{\delta} \mathrm{~L}_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)$ trivially satisfies constraint ( $\phi .1$ ). Moreover, by Corollary A.17, it satisfies constraint $(\phi .3)$. To prove constraints $(\phi .2)$ is satisfied, we need to show that

$$
\sum_{a \in \Gamma_{<a_{t}}} \phi_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}, a\right)+\sum_{a \in \Gamma_{>a_{t}} \cup\left\{a_{t}\right\}} \frac{1}{\delta} \mathrm{~L}_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}, a\right) \leq \phi_{t-1}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}\right)
$$

We prove this for the base case (i.e., when $a_{t}$ is the smallest element in $A$ ) and the inductive step (i.e., when $a_{t}$ has a predecessor $a^{*}$ ) separately:

Base Case: Suppose $a_{t}$ is the least element of $A$. Then, $\Gamma_{<a_{t}}$ is empty, reducing our goal to showing that

$$
\sum_{a \in A} \mathrm{~L}_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}, a\right) \leq \delta \phi_{t-1}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}\right)
$$

We know that $\phi_{t-1}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}\right)$ satisfies condition (I). Thus, by Lemma A.21,

$$
\delta \phi_{t-1}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}\right) \geq \mathrm{L}_{t-1}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}\right) \geq \sum_{a \in A} \mathrm{~L}_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}, a\right)
$$

finishing the proof for the base case.
Inductive Step: Let $a_{*}$ be the immediate predecessor of $a_{t}$. Since $\Gamma_{<a_{t}}=\Gamma_{<a^{*}} \cup\left\{a^{*}\right\}$, constraints ( $\phi .2$ ) for defining $\phi_{t}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}, a^{*}\right)$ is identical to (2). By inductive hypothesis, $\phi_{t}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}, a^{*}\right)$ exists and satisfies these constraints. Thus, inequality (2) holds, completing the induction.

Since $<_{t}$ is a well-order and the value of $\phi_{t}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)$ depends only on preceding values in this order, by the transfinite recursion theorem, the function $\phi_{t}$ is well-defined and exists.
A.3.3. Satisfying Conditions (I) to (III). Our main objective is to construct $\phi_{t}^{b}$ so that it fulfills conditions (I), (II), and (III). Constraints ( $\phi .1$ ) and ( $\phi .3$ ) directly imply conditions (I) and (II), respectively. It remains to show $\phi_{t}$ satisfies conditions (III).

First, we claim for each $b \in\{0,1\}$ and every transcript $\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}\right)$, $\sum_{a \in A} \phi_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}, a\right)$ is at most $\phi_{t-1}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}\right)$ : By constraint ( $\phi .2$ ) and non-negativity of $\mathrm{L}^{b}$, for every $a_{t}$,

$$
\sum_{a \in \Gamma_{<a_{t}} \cup\left\{a_{t}\right\}} \phi_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right) \leq \phi_{t-1}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}\right)
$$

Thus, when $A$ is finite and $a^{\prime}$ is the maximum element of $A$, we have

$$
\sum_{a \in A} \phi_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}, a\right)=\sum_{a \in \Gamma_{<a^{\prime} \cup\left\{a^{\prime}\right\}}} \phi_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}, a^{\prime}\right) \leq \phi_{t-1}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}\right)
$$

Moreover, when $A$ is infinite and $a_{1}^{\prime}<_{A} a_{2}^{\prime}<_{A} \ldots$ are the sorted elements of $A$, we have

$$
\sum_{a \in A} \phi_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}, a\right)=\lim _{k \rightarrow \mathbb{N}} \sum_{a \in \Gamma_{<a_{k}^{\prime} \cup\left\{a_{k}^{\prime}\right\}}} \phi_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}, a_{k}^{\prime}\right) \leq \phi_{t-1}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}\right)
$$

The rest of proof is identical to the proof given in [18]. We repeat it for completeness. For the sake of contradiction, suppose there exists $b \in\{0,1\}$ and $\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}\right)$ such that

$$
\sum_{a \in A} \phi_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}, a\right)<\phi_{t-1}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}\right)
$$

Fix $b$. As $\phi_{t}^{b}$ is lower bounded by $\mathrm{L}_{t}^{b} / \delta$, this implies that for every $a_{t} \in A$, in the optimization problem determining the value of $\phi_{t}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)$, constraint ( $\phi .2$ ) for $b$ is not tight. Consequently, for every $a_{t} \in A$, we must have had

$$
\phi_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)-e^{-\epsilon} \phi_{t}^{1-b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)=\mu_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)-e^{-\epsilon} \mu_{t}^{1-b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)
$$

otherwise, the value of $\phi_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)$ could have increased, which contradicts the maximality of $\phi_{b}^{t}$.
Taking a sum over all $a_{t} \in A$, we get
(4) $\sum_{a_{t} \in A} \delta \phi_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)-e^{-\epsilon} \delta \sum_{a_{t} \in A} \phi_{t}^{1-b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)=\mu_{t-1}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}\right)-e^{-\epsilon} \mu_{t-1}^{1-b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}\right)$

By (II) and the inductive hypothesis, we know that the RHS is at least

$$
\delta \phi_{t-1}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}\right)-e^{-\epsilon} \delta \phi_{t-1}^{1-b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}\right)
$$

Plugging this to (4) and reformulating it, we get

$$
\sum_{a_{t} \in A} \phi_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)-\phi_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}\right) \geq e^{-\epsilon}\left(\sum_{a_{t} \in A} \phi_{t}^{1-b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)-\phi_{t}^{1-b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}\right)\right)
$$

By (3), the LHS is negative, implying that the RHS is negative too. Thus, $\sum_{a \in A} \phi_{t}^{1-b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}, a\right)<\phi_{t-1}^{1-b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}\right)$. Hence, by an identical argument, we have

$$
\sum_{a_{t} \in A} \phi_{t}^{1-b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)-\phi_{t}^{1-b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}\right) \geq e^{-\epsilon}\left(\sum_{a_{t} \in A} \phi_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)-\phi_{t}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}\right)\right)
$$

which is a contradiction when $\epsilon>0$, which implies that condition (III) holds.

# APPENDix B. OVERVIEW OF [20] 

For $\epsilon \geq 0$, let $\mathcal{M}: S_{\mathcal{M}} \times Q_{\mathcal{M}} \rightarrow S_{\mathcal{M}} \times A_{\mathcal{M}}$ be an $\epsilon$-DP IM w.r.t. a neighboring relation $\sim$. Suppose that $\mathcal{M}$ has discrete answer distributions. Vadhan and Wang [20] shows that for any two neighboring initial states $s_{0}$ and $s_{1}$, there exists an IPM $\mathcal{P}$ such that for each $b \in\{0,1\}$, the mechanisms $\mathcal{M}\left(s_{b}\right)$ and $\mathcal{P} \circ^{*} \mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon, 0}(b)$ are identical. In this section, we overview the construction of $\mathcal{P}$ and show it satisfies the following property:

Claim B.1. For any $t \in \mathbb{N}$ and any query sequence $\left(q_{1}, \ldots, q_{t}\right) \in Q_{\mathcal{M}}^{t}$, if the distributions of the first $t$ answers of $\mathcal{M}\left(s_{0}\right)$ and $\mathcal{M}\left(s_{1}\right)$ to the queries $\left(q_{1}, \ldots, q_{t}\right)$ are identical, then for every $b \in\{0,1\}$, when $\mathcal{P} \circ^{*} \mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon, 0}(b)$ receives the queries $q_{1}, \ldots, q_{t}, \mathcal{P}$ generates answers itself, without interacting with $\mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon, 0}(b)$.

Since $\delta=0, \mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon, 0}(b)$ returns $(b, \perp)$ with probability $\frac{e^{\epsilon}}{1+e^{\epsilon}}$ and $(1-b, \perp)$ otherwise. For each $b$ and query sequence $\left(q_{1}, \ldots, q_{t}\right) \in Q_{\mathcal{M}}^{t}$, let $\mu_{q_{1}, \ldots, q_{t}}^{\mathcal{M}\left(s_{b}\right)}$ denote the distribution of the first $t$ answers of $\mathcal{M}\left(s_{b}\right)$ in response to $q_{1}, \ldots, q_{t}$. If $\epsilon=0$, then define $\nu_{q_{1}, \ldots, q_{t}}^{b}$ to be identical to $\mu_{q_{1}, \ldots, q_{t}}^{\mathcal{M}\left(s_{b}\right)}$. Otherwise, set

$$
\nu_{q_{1}, \ldots, q_{t}}^{b}=\frac{e^{\epsilon} \mu_{q_{1}, \ldots, q_{t}}^{\mathcal{M}\left(s_{b}\right)}-\mu_{q_{1}, \ldots, q_{t}}^{\mathcal{M}\left(s_{1-b}\right)}}{e^{\epsilon}-1}
$$

For $t \in \mathbb{N}, b \in\{0,1\}$, and $\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}\right) \in\left(Q_{\mathcal{M}} \times A_{\mathcal{M}}\right)^{t-1} \times Q$, if $\nu_{q_{1}, \ldots, q_{t-1}}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}\right)>0$, the function $T_{q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}}: A_{\mathcal{M}} \rightarrow[0,1]$ is defined as

$$
T_{q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}}^{b}\left(a_{t}\right)=\frac{\nu_{q_{1}, \ldots, q_{t}}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t}\right)}{\nu_{q_{1}, \ldots, q_{t-1}}^{b}\left(q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}\right)}
$$

Vadhan and Wang [20] define $\mathcal{P}$ as follows: The initial state of $\mathcal{P}$ is (null, ()$)$, where null is an empty field and () represents an empty sequence. Let $h$ denote the sequence. Let $(r, \perp)$ denote the outcome of $\mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon, 0}(b)$. After interacting with $\mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon, 0}(b), \mathcal{P}$ updates null to $r$. Moreover, upon receiving a query $q$ and before returning an answer $a, \mathcal{P}$ appends $q$ and $a$ to the history sequence $h$. To generate a response $a$ to a query $q, \mathcal{P}$ samples $a$ from the distribution $T_{h, q}^{r}$, where $h$ is the history of all previous queries and answers.

We observe that as long as $T_{h, q}^{0}$ and $T_{h, q}^{1}$ are identical, $\mathcal{P}$ does not need to know the value of $r$. Thus, to defer interaction with $\mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon, 0}(b)$, we define $\mathcal{P}$ to interact with $\mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon, 0}(b)$ only when these distributions are different for the first time.
Proof of Claim B.1. That the distributions $\mu_{q_{1}, \ldots, q_{t}}^{\mathcal{M}\left(s_{0}\right)}$ and $\mu_{q_{1}, \ldots, q_{t}}^{\mathcal{M}\left(s_{1}\right)}$ are identical implies that for every $k \leq t, \mu_{q_{1}, \ldots, q_{k}}^{\mathcal{M}\left(s_{0}\right)}$ and $\mu_{q_{1}, \ldots, q_{k}}^{\mathcal{M}\left(s_{1}\right)}$ are identical. Consequently, by definition, both distributions $\nu_{q_{1}, \ldots, q_{k}}^{0}$ and $\nu_{q_{1}, \ldots, q_{k}}^{1}$ are identical to $\mu_{q_{1}, \ldots, q_{k}}^{0}$. Therefore, the conditional distributions $T_{q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}}^{0}$ and $T_{q_{1}, \ldots, a_{t-1}, q_{t}}^{1}$ used by $\mathcal{P}$ are also identical, implying that $\mathcal{P}$ does not interact with $\mathrm{RR}_{\epsilon, 0}$ to generate the first $t$ answers.

abstract:
Many intended uses of differential privacy involve a $\textit{continual
mechanism}$ that is set up to run continuously over a long period of time,
making more statistical releases as either queries come in or the dataset is
updated. In this paper, we give the first general treatment of privacy against
$\textit{adaptive}$ adversaries for mechanisms that support dataset updates and
a variety of queries, all arbitrarily interleaved. It also models a very
general notion of neighboring, that includes both event-level and user-level
privacy.
  We prove several $\textit{concurrent}$ composition theorems for continual
mechanisms, which ensure privacy even when an adversary can interleave queries
and dataset updates to the different composed mechanisms. Previous concurrent
composition theorems for differential privacy were only for the case when the
dataset is static, with no adaptive updates. Moreover, we also give the first
interactive and continual generalizations of the "parallel composition theorem"
for noninteractive differential privacy. Specifically, we show that the
analogue of the noninteractive parallel composition theorem holds if either
there are no adaptive dataset updates or each of the composed mechanisms
satisfies pure differential privacy, but it fails to hold for composing
approximately differentially private mechanisms with dataset updates.
  We then formalize a set of general conditions on a continual mechanism $M$
that runs multiple continual sub-mechanisms such that the privacy guarantees of
$M$ follow directly using the above concurrent composition theorems on the
sub-mechanisms, without further privacy loss. This enables us to give a simpler
and more modular privacy analysis of a recent continual histogram mechanism of
Henzinger, Sricharan, and Steiner. In the case of approximate DP, ours is the
first proof showing that its privacy holds against adaptive adversaries.
